region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these, but I made a pan gravy with onions after I fried the chops.  After frying the chops, I fried sliced onions in the pan with the oil left over from the frying, then once they were caramelized, I added the wine to deglaze the pan and let it cook down a little.  Then I added two tablespoons of flour and cooked that while stirring it in the pan to get the raw flour taste out. I added the can of soup to the pan and stirred that until it was blended. I didn't add as much milk as the recipe calls for, but basically I just added a little at a time and then stirred and cooked it until it was the consistency of what I like in a gravy.  Add a little salt and pepper to the gravy to season it. I poured the gravy over the chops and baked it and WOW!  These were the most amazing pork chops we've ever had. I also made them without the breading, just seasoned them with season salt and seared them in the pan and then did the same gravy and my family was blown away again then.  The pan gravy rocks.

text:
I have made this recipe twice, once with the white wine & once with apple juice (per another review). Both times my family loved them. I should say that I did change a couple of things. First I wasn't sure if my picky eater would eat the sauce so I kept it on the side instead of pouring it over the chops, second since I was leaving it on the side I added one sweet onion to a pan and some oil, cooked down the onion then added milk, juice or wine and the cream of mushroom. Lastly I only cooked the chops for about 40 min to keep them from drying out. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I have made this several times and finally felt I needed to review it because it is fabulous. I took other reviews into consideration and when I make it I use more wine than called for (I don't measure exact) and I also saut some baby Bella mushrooms in the pan after browning the pork and throw them in with the sauce. Cooking time is not as long as the recipe calls for, I generally do 20/20 or a little longer. I think it depends on how thick the chops are and how many. Also, to cut down on fat, I use the low fat cream of mushroom soup and it's perfect. I serve over brown rice with a salad. My boyfriend loves this meal. *I wanted to update this to add that I use a Penzey's Pork Chop spice in this dish, and I both season the pork before browning and shake a fair amount into the sauce before pouring over the pork while baking.  I really think this spice makes the dish for us and would recommend it for anyone who uses Penzey's spices.  My boyfriend LOVES this meal and would ask for it every night if he could.

text:
This turned out really well for me.  The flavor was wonderful, and the chops were so tender you could cut them with a fork.  It does take a while to prep and cook, but it is a great Sunday supper recipe.  I followed the recipe as written as far as ingredients, but I did have to modify the cooking time, probably because I had thin pork chops.  Five minutes per side was too long on the frying time, and it needed about 45 minutes after the sauce was added instead of thirty. Also two cups of bread crumbs was way more than I needed.  Next time I will probably use about half of that.  This recipe will definitely be a keeper at my house.

This is my new go to recipe for pork chops. I make the recipe just as it says. I never know what kind of wine to use when something says "dry white wine", so I have tried a few different ones. Most recently I used sauvignon blanc and that was good. I would suggest reducing the cooking time unless your chops are really thick. I cook mine for about 1 hour total. 30 minutes in the oven, add sauce, and then bake for another 30 minutes. Best served with corn and mashed potatoes.

Delicious. I didn't have white wine so I used champagne instead and it was so yummy! I agree with the others that the pan needed sprayed with cooking spray and the sauce was only really enough for 4 chops. And the baking time was off - I did it for about 50 minutes total.

text:
This recipe was very easy and yummy.  I made a few subtle changes.  Used Panko to bread the chops, instead of plain breadcrumbs.  Also added some sauteed mushrooms to the sauce, along with some black pepper, parsley, and a tablespoon of Gravy Master. I used pretty thick chops, and found that they only needed to be baked for about 35-40 minutes total.  This recipe will definitely be marked as one of the family favorites.

Great pork chop recipe.  Made it exactly how the recipe is written exept I used two large pork chops instead of 6.  There was enough sauce/gravy for the mashed potatoes.  Also, I only needed to cook the pork chops in the oven for 40 minutes before adding the sauce.  ETA: I have made this Gluten free by using GF flour, GF bread crumbs and GF cream of mushroom and it comes out wonderful.

text:
This was amazingly delish.  My chops were very thick lovely T chops and so I cooked a little longer.  To those who thought it was a lot of clean up, I did not.  Yes...several containers were used but while chops were browning I quickly washed up breading bowls.  Once in the oven I scrubbed up the pan.  Now one could really make the clean up a throw away by using paper plates for flour and bread crumbs.  Recipe was well worth the small amount of effort...simply delicious.  Will probably add sauteed mushrooms next time around.  This will undoubtably be a go to pork chop recipe for us.  Try it...you will like it.  BTW...I used a little left over Chardonnay for the wine.

userID:
4096397
Display Name:
KathieBr
isPro:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Alright,evil cook that I am I of course made alterations I am rating 4 stars for that reason. I seasoned 2 - 1 inch bone in center cut chops with onion powder, garlic powder and seasoning salt,regular s & p, beat two eggs Dredged the chops in flour, dipped in the eggs and then in a mixture of seasoned breadcrumbs mixed with panko 

Fried the chops in 1 inch of canola and 4 turns of olive oil Sliced 1/3 of a sweet vidalia onion, 8 oz of fresh mushrooms (canned,ew) and chopped 2-3 cloves of garlic and sauteed til caramelized

Chops baking away at 350 I get out 2 cans of cr. of mushroom soup, poured in whole milk to the consistency I prefer, then added some white wine. Seasoned the sauce with some s&p, added the sauteed veggies

At 25 minutes I decided against my better judgement that I would add the sauce However, I only spooned on about 1/3 cup to each chop, with a hefty amount of the mushrooms and onions. Decided I didn't want to drown the chops. Cooked another 20 minutes

OK SEASON SEASON SEASON! I used more than the original recipe called for on only two chops I added salt and pepper, garlic, onions, fresh mushrooms, and it just lacked that finish!

 I would add 10 - 15 minutes to the cooking time, perhaps 35 then add sauce and cook an additional 15 or a bit more. These were moist and tender, my only complaint is with the breading, you need to season like crazy, the gravy/sauce as written would be like a paste without what I added and still that was not enough.

This was my first time making this, and it was easy and the meat came out SUPER SOFT and cooked perfect. All that despite me messing up and mixing recipes. I used veg oil instead of olive, forgot to cover with foil in the oven, added a 10ish drops Worcestershire sauce (don't know if it was enough to make a difference), and double breaded the chops (and I used 3 big ones not 6). Also used 1 can mushroom with roasted garlic soup, and poultry and italian seasoning for the marinade. As with any recipe, you can play around with flavors, which I will next time, but frying until brown and then at least 45 mins in the oven cooks the meat perfect. Thanks!

city:

country:

text:
I just made this last night and it was a hit! My bf was skeptical about the pork chops when I told him I was going to make it. After the first bite, he turned to me and jumped in exclaimed that it was delicious. He raved about it and said this was a recipe to keep and make again. He said it was moist and flavorful.   So when I made this recipe, I used thin cut pork chops. I would suggest lightly season it with the garlic powder and seasoning salt or use low sodium mushroom soup if you're going to do thin cut. It was a little salty for my taste but because I served it over rice, it evened out. I did as another reviewer suggested and sauteed onions and smashed garlic into the soup base for more flavor. I tossed in a little more wine as well. I browned the pork chops for about 3-4 minutes each side and put it in the oven for 18 minutes and then another 18 minutes with the soup base. It was perfect!

text:
I've made this numerous times and it's PERFECT... but I've substituted cream of celery or other similar soup for the mushroom soup and eliminated the wine and milk (a non-mushroom, non-wine person here) BUT added the following instead of the milk and wine:  1 package of dry pork gravy mix made according to package directions.  I use Pioneer Brand Roast Pork Gravy Mix, which makes 2 delicious cups of gravy.  Add the gravy with the soup (blend until smooth before adding to pork chops) instead of milk and wine   for the last 30 min.  AND BE SURE TO GET YOUR CHOPS GOLDEN BROWN/CRISP in Step 2 of the original recipe.  EXCELLENT!

text:
Made this for dinner last night - thought it was fabulous.  I had purchased pork chops not knowing what I would make, looked up recipes, and this looked the best - plus, I could make it with ingredients on hand!  I cut the cooking time down to 20 minutes before sauce/20 minutes after sauce.  Only used a bit of sauce during the baking process, heated up the sauce in a pan, and used the rest for those who like sauce (some in my family don't).  Also, I only had cream of chicken soup, so used this, and added a clove of garlic (crushed) to kick up the flavor a bit, plus an extra dash of wine.  Will definitely be making this again!

text:
These are fabulous. Usually chops and chicken are bathed in condensed soup because they get so dry. By breading these and searing them they stay so moist! I sprinkle each side with seasoned salt and garlic powder before breading. Then, I sear them in my cast iron skillet so I can just move the whole works straight into the oven. I also like the outside crisp, so I keep the gravy separate. I bake the chops for an hour and cover with gravy just before eating. These are fabulous!!!!!

These were good.  I enjoyed the gravy.  I sauteed some onion and garlic then added fresh mushrooms and added one can golden mushroom and one can cream of chicken and mushroom. Also I used crushed stove top as my breading and I really enjoyed it.

userID:
5686747
Display Name:
Cheryl Ganley
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2210187.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not generally a big fan of pork chops, but these were great! I did customize the recipe by reading others reviews and I think that helped. I used some think cut bone in pork chops seasoned with creole seasoning and garlic powder. Breaded according to directions and pan fried. Like others have said it is really important to get a nice browning on the breading. I then put my chops in the oven and started on the sauce. I sauteed onions, garlic and fresh mushrooms in the pan I fried the chops in to get all the tasty bibbets. I added some pinot grigio to deglaze the pan. Then add a can of golden mushroom and cream of mushroom along with the milk and let simmer on the stove top. I believe the golden mushroom soup was a must because it gave more flavor then just plan old cream of mushroom. Seasoned the sauce with some more creole seasoning for a little extra kick. Took the chops out of the oven after 40 min. and put the sauce on top and served. YUMMY! Didn't need to add sauce to the chops and bake again. I would have lost that crunch that I like so much. This is a great sauce that I bet would be good on pan fried chicken breast too. Will 100% make again. Thanks for a great base recipe as well as all the great tips in the reviews.

text:
I got home last night to make this and found I didn't have everything for the sauce.  I went ahead and made the pork chops without the sauce.  I followed the recipe until I got to the breadcrumbs. I only had about half the breadcrumbs I needed. I spotted some cornmeal on the shelf and decided to use that with the breadcrumbs.  I used tenderized pork chops and sauted(sp?) them in veg oil until the breadcrumbs were golden brown then baked covered in the oven for 30 minutes.  They were great!!  Very tender and moist. I made real mashed potatoes with brown gravy. The next time I make these I will make sure I have everything for the sauce because I think that will make it even better.  I am giving this recipe 4 stars even though I didn't follow the recipe to the letter.  The baking method alone makes it worth the 4 stars.

I made this tonight for the first time.  I made it exactly as the recipe said to except instead of measuring out the garlic powder and seasoning salt I just sprinkled those onto the pork chops straight out of their containers.  My whole family really liked the pork chops.  Even my very picky kids liked it.  I was a little worried about the length of cooking time in the oven because the pork chops that I used were boneless and thin.  However I followed the exact amount of cooking time of 1 and a 1/2 hours and I was surprised to find that the pork chops came out very tender.  I cut them with my fork.  No knife needed.  The sauce was good.  This is exactly the kind of pork chop recipe I've been looking for.

2CatsandMe

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were nice and tender, but I think I will cut the wine down some.  Just didn't seem to go too well with this, just my taste buds. This is a fairly easy recipe and made this in no time.   5 minutes for each side on med-high I found way to long, I only cooked them about 2-1/2 minutes per side and they were very crisp and nicely browned.  I had no problem with the breading falling off at all.  The trick to this is and when breading any type of food, it must dry, not damp, not wet.  After breading the food, put on a rack (cooling racking on a cookies sheet) and if possible let sit for an hour in the refrigerator.  (I only let these rest for about 30 minutes).  You will definitely see a difference in your  breaded foods.

text:
I can't figure out what all the fuss is about!  Or maybe my taste buds were just having an off day.  For the work involved (even adding cayenne pepper to the flour & sauted onions & mushroom to the sauce) I found this recipe too bland.  Also, if you fry medium sized pork chops for a total of 10 minutes, then bake them for a total of 1 1/2 hours at 350, they will have the texture of cardboard.  My boneless chops were about 3/4 inch thick, I fried for 1 to 2 minutes per side, then baked for 30 minutes, added sauce and baked for an additional 10 minutes (I nuked sauce 1st to partially heat) and that was really to long.  The chops were a bit dry and didn't "fall apart" as other reviews have said.  Sorry!  Probably will not make again.

text:
I made this recipe again for the second time, and made a few changes to the original recipe.  I found the meat a little bland so, this time I spiced the meat with garlic powder, some onion powder, fresh cracked pepper and a little Lawry's seasoning salt before breading the meat.  I also doubled the sauce by using 1 can cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of mushroom with roasted garlic soup, then doubled the amounts of milk and wine.  Since I already had a bottle of white Rhine opened in the fridge, this is what I used in the recipe (and, I'm really glad I did, since this wine added a wonderful taste and aroma to the whole dish)!  I served this with creamy mashed potatoes, cheesy brocolli, and chunky-style cinnamon applesauce. Yummy!

userID:

Display Name:
Eileen Moynihan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1625148.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am going to start with the fact that I have never been a fan of pork chops, but, times are tough and my boyfriends mom gave us a package of them and I know that I can turn to allrecipes to help me with anything I want to make. I did follow some of the other reviewers suggestions and made a couple of changes. We are not mushroom fans, so I used cream of celery, and I didn't have any white wine so I filled the can of cream of celery soup 3/4 of the way with milk and added that to the gravy, which I started on the stovetop. I also seasoned the flour and bread crumbs with garlic powder and natures seasoning along with the chops themselves. There are 3 of us, so I only used 3 pork chops, and didn't change any other measurements. instead of browning on the stovetop and transferring to another pan, I used my cast iron skillet and put it into the oven after the chops were browned (why dirty an extra pan?) I didn't bake them as long either and if I had, the chops would have been dry.  My whole family enjoyed this, including myself. I may even start buying pork chops and making them this way.

Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
4006081
Display Name:
corvy
isPro:
False
followersCount:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If 5 stars are "the best" then 3 stars must be "good".  This is a good, solid, comfort food recipe.  I used two 2" thick boneless pork chops.  After reading comments about bland pork and because of their size (9oz ea), I used the full teaspoon of both garlic powder and season salt on my chops before flouring them. I fried them for just 2-3 minutes per side, top, bottom, and all around to avoid burning them.  My pan was smoking hot at medium-high.  I used a 7x11 dish and the gravy reached about halfway up the sides of the chops.  I followed the recipe with these adjustments:  For the gravy,I doubled the wine to 2/3 cup, added 1/2 tsp pepper, and mixed in 1 sauteed sliced onion.  I baked the chops just 20 minutes, added the sauce and baked for another 30 minutes with the foil and then 20 minutes more without the foil because the sauce was looking thin. The end result was tender pork chops that still had good texture and a sauce that needs tweaking.  Most of the flavor came from the breading on the chops.  Next time I'll try using golden mushroom soup, add sauteed mushrooms, and omit the milk to see if that helps. My husband liked it and I'm adding this recipe to our comfort food rotation.

text:
This is a great recipe.  I renamed it Stroganoff Pork Chops because it is a lot like the stroganoff sauce you make with beef.  Be careful not to use a dry white wine like sherry because the wine flavor can be too strong.  I've made it with Chardonnay and Pinot Grigio and like the flavors much better.  Thanks for adding another recipe to my box!

I totally screwed up this recipe and it still turned out great. I didn't dredge in flour first and I forgot the seasoned salt and garlic. My wife hates cream of mushroom soup but she loved this sauce and it made a terrific gravy.  Excellent recipe! This is my second review: We discovered that the reason this recipe was so good the first time was because I forgot the seasoned salt and garlic. We remembered it the second time we made it and ended up throwing out the leftovers! Do yourself a favor and at least leave out the seasoned salt.

text:
I loved the recipe!  I only salted the flour and didn't use the breadcrumbs because my kids won't eat anything breaded.  Made sure the pan was nice and hot and cooked 5 min on each side.  Cut the oven cooking time down a bit because I preheated to 375 by mistake.  I put the mushroom soup in the pan that I used to sautee the chops in, that way I got all the good crispy bits in the sauce.  Used 1/4 cup white wine and 1/4 cup sherry with the milk.  I just love the way sherry adds so much flavor!  Anyway, I will be making this easy and delicious recipe again!  Thanks for posting it!

These pork chops were PHENOMENAL!!! I used crushed up fried onions instead of bread crumbs. I didn't see the point in the egg and bread crumbs, so I skipped that part.  I added my seasonings to the flour before dredging them.  I cooked them a big longer in the frying pan, maybe 10 minutes on each side.  (I had very thick chops.)  I covered and baked them, not as long as the recipe called for, and made the sauce on the stovetop.  To be honest, the sauce made with plain old cream of mushroom soup was bland as could be.  The wine didn't do a thing for it.  Would pouring it over the chops and baking that last 30 minutes make a difference in the flavor of the sauce?  I don't know.  I liked the chops well enough on their own to make them again this way, though.

text:
What a great recipe! Changes that I had to make in order to accommodate to my family's tastes and available ingredients: I used 1/4 cup italian breadcrumbs and 1 3/4 cups of crushed ritz crackers (only because I ran out of the italian breadcrumbs) and the breading tasted so buttery and delicious! I seasoned the pork chops with Lawry's seasoning salt, fresh cracked black pepper, onion and garlic powder. I also added 1 tbsp rubbed sage, one crushed garlic clove and fresh cracked pepper to the sauce. I only baked 30/30 minutes and the pork chops were perfectly tender and oh so juicy. We served them over white rice & steamed broccoli/cauliflower. Such a comforting and filling dinner. Thank you for this recipe, I plan on making this over and over again.

text:
My husband and family friend stated these were the best pork chops I ever made and that they ever tasted - quite the compliment to the recipe! 
I used a Tastefully Simple Bistro Portabella soup mix (mixed with 3 cups water and one cup of sourcream) instead of the golden mushroom soup. I also took plain bread crumbs and seasoned them myself with basil, parsley, garlic, onion, pepper, and a dash of salt. 
I served them aside mashed potatoes. The pork chops were so tender we could cut them with a fork. 
After reading some reviews I did lay out a plan for clean up and handling the mess so it was pretty simple and kept to a minimum.
I will reccomend this recipe to all my friends and family - fairly simple using basic ingredients and very tasty.

Display Name:
Sarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/166172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for a few years now (it's a favorite of my husband's). It's definitely become a staple in our household and with very few modifications, although a few over the years to tweak it for us.

The first (and biggest) tweak that I do is use thin cut pork chops. This makes it SO MUCH faster of a recipe. For the cook times I only do 15 minutes at a time (with thin cut pork chops, mind you) -- so 15 minutes, then add cream of mushroom/milk topping, then another 15 minutes. Works out great for us, so delicious!

The only other change I've made over the years is adding only half a can of milk. So pour the cream of mushroom into a bowl and then pour the milk into the cream of mushroom can about halfway. This makes the sauce a little bit thicker and we like that.

Overall this is a great recipe. We've never made it with anything other than the thin cut pork chops, so it is a fairly quick and easy meal for us on weeknights. Served with corn on the cob, green beans (or better yet green bean casserole) and it's perfect.

I'm going to keep looking for a better recipe for chops, this one didn't quite cut it.

text:
I made this recipe tonight. I took the advice of some other users and omitted the white wine.  In its place, I used sour cream.  I also used cream of chicken soup because I had it on hand and my family is not big on mushrooms.  Other than this, I prepared the chops as directed.  I think they would have been just as enjoyable without the "gravy", as it didn't thin to actual gravy as expected.  In any case, the chops were tender and the dish was pretty enjoyable.  However, I may try the white wine next time or I will completely skip the "gravy" and stick to the seasoned chops.  All in all, not a bad dish.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/667869.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved this recipe.  I made as directed with the exception of adding half a small diced onion and two large garlic cloves that I sauteed after the chops were browned. I topped the chops with half this mixture and then added the rest to the gravy. Very tender and flavorful.  (We ate them with Worcestershire sauce on the side).

***Update:  I made this yesterday exactly as the recipe calls, except for the cooking method, which I used the slow cooker, which made it even better!  After seasoning, I browned the chops, then put in slow cooker with 1 c liquid (I used broth, but next time will use 1/2 water b/c they were just a tad salty).    Cooked on low for 7 hours, then added the cream of mushroom/wine mixture, topped that with 1/2 sliced onion and some fresh mushrooms, cooked for another hour and oh my word!!!!  Delish!

text:
This recipe was amazing. I have never loved pork chops, but I can honestly say that I loved these. I am on weight watchers, so I made some changes to the recipe that made it more point friendly without sacrificing flavor. For the egg wash, I used 3 eggs whites instead of the 2 whole eggs. I cut the 4 tablespoons of olive oil down to one and used some Pam with that to fry the chops. I used Campbell's 98% FF cream of mushroom soup and skim milk. I cut the bread crumbs   to one cup, which was plenty to coat the chops. This recipe was truly the best. I would give it 6 stars if I could.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this twice- the first tasted excellent, the second was a soggy mess. As others have mentioned, the thickness of the pork chop makes all the difference. The thicker the pork chop = the soggier the pork chop (due to all the excess juices escaping into the breading), which makes browning the chop on the skillet beforehand, pretty useless. 
I also prefer to make the sauce on the side, since it makes the breading soggy otherwise. All in all, a really delicious dish (when done properly, that is!).

Display Name:
Melissa Hofer Adam

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was doubtful I would like this... but I actually loved it as did my husband.  I followed suggestions from others & changed a few things on my own.  

1. Did a garlic/herb rub, tenderized meat
2. Dipped in egg, then flour, then egg, then bread crumbs
3. Pan fried only a few minutes, not 5, just barely golden...
4. Baked covered alone for 20 minutes
5. Then added sauce and baked an additional 30 minutes

My hubby raved about this, and loved the gravy with potatoes.  

Sauce changes I made: 
~1 can cream of mushroom
~1 can cream of chicken
~1 cup milk
~sauteed onions with mushrooms in pork  skillet w/ a little wine and butter
~Added wine to taste, maybe 1/3-1/2 cup?
~Heated up on stove

Yummy!!!  This is going on our regular rotation per request of the hubby.  Thanks so much for a great recipe!!  Contrary to other reviews, I didn't really think this was much work at all, I think I can actually make it fairly quickly the next time I make it.  Excellent!

country:

text:
Great recipe! I listened to the advice of HOLLY9000 and it came out amazing. Almost like pork marsala. The key alterations are definitely as follows: Reduce oven time(I used boneless chops and browned them for about 3-4 mins on each side and then cooked for 20/20). Also, definitelyl add sauteed onions & mushrooms to the doubled sauce. I sauteed them right in the pork grease and added about 1/2 cup of white wine and a pat of butter during cooking - then after liquid simmered off I added them to the sauce. My husband really does not like pork and he said I could make this one any time. Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
OH MY GOSH.... This is SOOOOO good!! I mean, it fell off my fork, it was so tender and juicy.  I altered it a little, with what I had at home.  I used cream of chicken mushroom soup, and I didn't have white wine.. so I put a little red wine in it for the taste. Also, I seasoned it with lots of garlic powder, pepper, and season salt.  I cooked the soup on the stovetop, with the milk and wine, and added a good bit of paprika and some sour cream I had in the fridge.  I added it to the pork and baked it.  I had very thin chops.. so I baked them 20 minutes alone and 20 minutes with the soup. This was so good, I can't wait to eat the leftovers.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
This was outstanding, and hubby agreed (and he's not a big pork chop fan!). I doubled the sauce like other reviewers and added bit of garlic powder & ground cayenne to give little kick. Also, like another reviewer, I heated the sauce on the stovetop then poured over the finished chops to serve. Note: I only needed 1C (or less) of bread crumb mixture to cover chops liberally, so you can cut back on amt of ingredients there.

text:
My husband and I LOVED this.  I used some seasoned croutons that were getting a little long in the tooth.  I ground them in the food processor, and used them instead of the breadcrumbs.  I also used bone-in pork chops, they tend to do better when you are cooking them for this length of time.  They stay nice and moist.  I also added a carton of baby bellas and 1/2 cup of onions, which I carmelized to the sauce.  We put this over rice and served with glazed carrots.  Next time I will double the sauce, so there will be plenty for the rice.

This recipe was delicious!  Although, after reading some of the reviews about the sauce being a bit bland, I added some garlic powder (about 1/2 tsp), a Tbsp of dried onion flakes, and a little bit of salt to the soup mixture before adding to chops.  I also used chicken broth instead of wine (didn't have any).  Next time, I think I'll use boneless pork chops.  This recipe is a keeper!!

I made this last night, and was very surprised how wonderful it was!!  I made it with no white wine, and just a little extra milk.  I did not have any bread crumbs on hand, so used some croutons from my pantry.  I followed others advice and made sure to really brown before baking.  I made recipe with only 4 chops but full recipe for gravy/sauce, and it was wonderful!!  I also changed baking time to 45/25--just perfect!  I am a very picky eater, and I really like my pork chops with breading, these were PERFECT tasting!! Not dry at all, and still a little crunchy/crispy---and awesome flavor!!!  Will definitely make again!!

text:
My market only had thin chops.  Sprinkled 7 chops generously with seasoning salt & garlic powder.  Didn't have white wine, so I used vermouth.  I mixed 1/2 cup plain bread crumbs with 1/2 cup Italian-style bread crumbs--just right for 7 thin chops.  Baked 40 minutes, then added mushroom sauce for 30 minutes.  They came out perfectly!  The sauce was so creamy, and the chops were quite tender and juicy.  Even my ULTRA picky dad liked them!  Cook time is a bit long, but easy (I don't even cook!) and delicious meal with just plain rice.  Not at all bland!  Thanks for a great recipe!

userID:
369646
Display Name:
MOMASITA
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

2

134
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe a few months ago, but living in Florida, I hesitate to use the oven in the summer months. I found that I can make this dish on the stove top, and it turns out even better! I add a couple of cloves of garlic to the oil, add chops (dredging & breading them a few hours in advance really makes the breading stay on them!)Once they are cooked, (15 minutes is fine for 1/2" chops)I remove them to a plate, tent w/foil, then add fresh sliced mushrooms, more fresh garlic, diced onion and saute. Deglaze w/wine, scrape & add cream of mushroom w/herbs & garlic soup, mixing. Let simmer til hot, throw the chops on top & serve. No hot oven! & the breading stays crunchy, at least on the top!!! :)

text:
I used very thin pork chops so only cooked 40/20.  I sauteed some mushroom slices in the pan from the pork chops when I browned them and added to the oven the last 10 minutes of cooking.  The sauce was a little too much white wine for me so next time I'll omit it or lessen it and make up for the liquid with milk. I really enjoyed the sauce over homemade mashed potatoes.  Next time I'm not sure I'll do the bread crumbs because as a lot of people said it turned mushy in the oven.  By the way- you can prepare everything ahead of time to save time.  I breaded the chops and put them in the fridge- you could even brown them and mix the soup up and leave them in the fridge until you're ready to bake it.  OK- I just made this again and substituted chix broth for the wine and skipped the bread crumbs.  It was so much better.  I served it over mashed pot. and cooked it the entire time- I used very thick bone in chops this time.  it was yummy.

text:
Oh so good. Very, very tender. The key is to brown the chops well so the breading sticks. I used three 1/2" thick center cut boneless pork loin chops and *roasted garlic* mushroom soup for added flavor. I also sauted a small diced onion in the pan I browned the chops in, added the wine to the onions, and then the soup and milk. Later I poured the sauce on top of the chops. 30 minutes covered and 30 minutes with the sauce and covered was plenty of time. Very good!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a terrific recipe.  I didn't have wine, so used left over sparkling cider.  Apple juice also would have worked.  To cut calories, I trimmed all visible fat from the chops before cooking, and used low-fat cream of mushroom soup.  Rather than mixing the sauce ingredients in a bowl, I mixed them in the pan used to brown the chops.  This increased the flavor by incorporating the browned bits and pan juices.  The only thing I'd do differently in the future would be to double the sauce ingredients.  This was just so great that we would have happily used twice the gravy.  Thanks, so much, for sharing!

text:
I tried this recipe the first time following the instructions exactly. I made the following changes the second time and it turned out much better. I suggest cooking the pork chops for no more than 1 hour so they don't dry out unless your chops are extremly thick. The gravy was very thick so I added another can of soup, greatly increased the amount of milk, and added a package of Lipton onion soup mix so the gravy was flavorful, thinner, and was enough to go on the rice.

text:
This overall was a good recipe because the mushroom "sauce" really made the pork so moist and tender.  I found that I ended with better results with the soup mixture if I added a bit of lemon juice and used less milk (1/4 cup) - doing this makes the "sauce" less watered down.  I also seasoned the pork with onion powder, garlic salt and black pepper for more flavor.

text:
These pork chops were absolutely wonderful!  I didn't have Italian-seasoned bread crumbs, so I just used plain and added about a Tablespoon of Italian Seasoning.  I also didn't have the wine, but the recipe was good without it.  The pork chops were so tender, they fell off the bone.  My only complaint is the breading made it hard to tell the difference between the meat and the bone!

text:
It was  very good!  I skipped the breading as I wanted to reduce the carbs.  Instead I pan fried with onions and mushrooms for 5 min. per side.  Then I put it all in a 9x13 pan and covered with foil and baked 30 min.  Meanwhile, I mixed mushroom soup with 1/3 c. skim milk and 1/2 cup chicken broth, garlic powder, oregano, basil, ground pepper and garlic.  I added the mushroom soup mixture and baked 30 more minutes.  Pork chops were moist and tender.  Served the mushroom gravy over wild rice.  My family liked it so I will make it again.  I might try it with the wine next time, I just didn't have any on hand.

I judge recipes on if my husband goes back for seconds.  With this recipe he did. It was so delicious to us both!! I don't like mushrooms so I used cream of chicken instead. I was hesitant about using the wine but I used chardonnay and the "gravy" was so tasty with this recipe.  I also used thin, bone-in pork chops and did not smother them in gravy.  I fried on each side for 5 minutes, then baked in oven for 30 mins, and served the gravy on the side for the chops and brown rice.  I will use this recipe again and again.

text:
Ive made this several times since I found this recipe.  Family thinks its really good.  I think we prefer the golden mushroom soup but both are good.  Just a tip for those complaining of a lot of dishes.  When I have a recipe that calls for dredging etc, I just year off some foil and bend the edges for my dry ingredients.  I only use a small bowl, frying pan, and baking dish for this. Ball up foil dishes and toss in trash, couldnt get any easier!  Thanks for sharing recipe!!

text:
This is one of those recipes that I can't live without! WOW - I have never been one for pork chops, but maybe because I never had chops as good as this. If you want delicious, tender pork that falls apart, this should be your go-to recipe. I have made this numerous times now. I never egg/bread it. Just adds calories. But I do pan fry the chops in olive oil until browned nicely. Make sure you cover the chops with foil when cooking, this an important step. NO WINE? It's okay, use apple juice if you have it! This is one of my very favorite recipes. Enjoy!

The recipe requires a two step baking process that takes 1.5 hours alone. The prepararion is easy, but it does take time to complete the three step breading process. text:
My husband raved about how tender this was.  Said it was the best pork chop he'd ever had.  I baked the chops covered about 30 minutes, then poured the soup mixture (a mixture of 1/2 can cream of chicken, 1/2 can cream of mushroom, 1/2 cup wine and 1/4 cup milk) over the chops and baked covered another 40 minutes.  I used grated Parmesan cheese in place of the flour in an attempt to cut back a little bit on carbs.  Very tasty.  Very tender.  A keeper.

I'm giving this recipe five stars because I think had I not listened to a few of the other reviewers, this would've been delicious. But it wasn't. Oh, the pork was succulent and tender. I took half an hour off the cook time, and it was great. The sauce was awful. So, if you're reading other reviews and thinking, "Hey, that Golden Mushroom Soup mix-in sounds good," ABORT. I repeat, ABORT. Step awaaaaay from the golden mushroom soup, because it's god-freakin-awful. 

I will try this recipe again, and only, ONLY, change the cook time.

text:
Awesome recipe; however, I had to change a bit to fit our busy schedule.  I coated the pork chops as instructed and browned in frying pan.  I then placed the semi-fried chops in my crock pot with some sliced onions.  I mixed cream of mushroom with some chicken stock and poured over the fried chops and onion in the  pot.  I cooked on low for 7 hours.  When I came home from work the pork chops were fall off the bone delicious and ready to eat!  I served over rice with okra and used the gravy from the crock pot.  Fix this quite often and everyone loves it!!

text:
I made this recipe twice and each time received rave reviews from my family.  My husband typically does not care for breading, but he devoured these chops and, later in the evening, again remarked how very good dinner was.  In my book, that makes this recipe a keeper.  For those who don't care for the chops baked with the mushroom sauce,  I can offer another suggestion that is super easy.  Campbell's makes a new variety of tomato soup with chipotle -- it has a nice little kick to it.  In a small sauce pan, add the soup and 1/2 can of water (and/or a splash of white wine). Serve it drizzled over the baked chops (it's also great on mashed potatoes).

text:
I joined Allrecipes just so I could rate this recipe.  It is amazing.  I only made two pork chops (bone-in, 3/4 inch thick), but made the same amount of gravy, and I was glad I did. I used 1/2 a cup of chardonnay and 1/3 a cup of milk, and added a little black pepper. Oh, I also added a drained can of sliced mushrooms. Yum. I did like many of the others suggested and cooked the chops for only a 1/2 hour, added the gravy, and cooked for another half hour. The chops were fork tender. We ate this over rice, and licked up every morsel of gravy. I think I will try this recipe with chicken, it should be amazing as well.   Thanks for a new "in the rotation" recipe!

text:
Ok, I have to tell you, I have never rated any recipes before, but this one was worth the effort!! This is the best pork chop recipe I've ever had!! I followed all of the directions, except I sauted mushrooms and added them to the sauce. Also, knowing my oven all too well, I only baked these for 45 minutes. When I checked the internal temp, these were done. I just poured the sauce mixture over them and left them in the oven, turned off, until I finished the rest of the sides. They came out so flavorful and tender that the entire family was asking for seconds and wanting to know when I was going to make them again!! Thanks so much! This one is a keeper!!

country:

text:
This was just okay for our family. I did follow the recipe, including the long cook time. Chops were definitely tender and could be pulled apart with a fork. My kids thought the texture was "weird" for a pork chop. But hey, their favorite restaurant is McDonalds so I don't think their opinion hold a lot of weight. The sauce was good but it's obvious it's made with cream of mushroom soup. We found the breading completely unnecessary. Following the recipe exactly left the coating on the chops and did not turn it into mush, we just didn't think it brought much to the recipe. Because I usually will have all these ingredients on hand, I might make it again. The whole family said they could eat it again but would never request it. However, this is not anything I would make if I had to run to the store to get anything needed for it. The long cook time didn't bother me. I made myself busy with other household chores while it baked. A positive to it is the ability to walk away from it and not having to keep checking on it. I put it in the full time and only looked at it to add the sauce. I definitely would not have the time to cook this on a weekday schedule.

The most amazing pork chop recipe we have ever had.  I hesitated to make this because of frying then baking.  Why not just fry? But I decided to dive in.  I purchased boneless chops on sale so I had 12 chops, double the recipe. Well worth the time and effort.  Make sure to cover the chops when baking, as it states, to keep these moist.  You can cut these with a fork!!!!  LOVE IT

text:
Delicious and easy to prepare. I used Panko bread crumbs, added Italian seasoning and a sprinkle of cayenne pepper, and fried the pork chops in a large deep skillet until browned and crisp. Instead of baking, I prepared the mushroom gravy separately, using a large can of cream of mushroom soup and replacing the milk with extra white wine. I poured the hot gravy over the cooked pork chops and simmered for 15 min. more. Yum! Optional: Add another can or two of mushroom soup to make extra gravy to serve over mashed potatoes or jasmine rice. Enjoy!

text:
I fried the pork chops for about 3 minutes per side prior to baking them. I had really thick pork chops so I baked them for only 40 minutes before pulling them out to add the sauce. Unfortunately the chops were already at a temperature of 150 before I added the sauce, so I only cooked them 10 minutes longer.
All in all this was a good recipe, but be careful of the cooking times since my gravy ended up fairly watery due to the lack of cooking time, and my thick chops were somewhat dry the whole way through.

city:

country:
None
text:
It was THE BEST pork chop recipe.  EVER!   It was so moist and tender and had The Best Flavor.  The only thing I did differently was forgot the flour.  Used croutons for salad (Italian flavored) that I chopped to make crumbs about 1/4 cup and herb seasoned  stuffing to make 1.5-2 cups to have enough for 8 boneless pork chops. (Bought at Aldis) then used 3 eggs to make sure it was enough for 8.  (More than enough).  I had cooked some sliced fresh mushrooms in beef broth, so after the chops cooled 1 hour, I poured the soup/wine/milk mixture over them and then put some of the cooked mushrooms on top and followed directions to bake 30 more min.   I had NO IDEA it would taste so good, moist, and tender!   5 stars hands down.   My family loved it!!!

text:
The first time I made these, the meat was dry and tough. I think the pork chops were too thin and may have dried out while being browned.

The second time I made these, I went to the meat market and got thicker chops. They were delicious. I used almost double the wine (which was white sherry), milk and soup for extra moistness.  Terrific recipe, but it is a little time consuming. Also, next time I'll spray the baking dish with non-stick spray, because the pork chops stuck to the dish a little bit.

text:
I fried the prokchops till well done. 
Then put in oven for 30 mins. 
Took 1/2 red pepper, 1 c. Mushrooms,
1/4 of yellow onion, sauted in drippings. Turn heat on high added 1/2 the wine covered and simmered 5 mins. Then took 1/2 garlic clove and squeezed and diced with garlic press. Added 2 cans mushroom soup and brought to boil. 
Poured mixture over chops, back in oven covers 30 mins. 
Over rice with peas 
Excellent

text:
This is a great and quick recipe. I made a few changes. Instead of using canned cream of mushroom soup, I used my homemade version of it. I added some sage to the rub for the chops. Also, the cooking time is too long. I cooked it for 25 minutes without sauce, and then another 15 minutes with the sauce, and they turned out perfect. If it hadn't required canned condensed soup, I would have given it 5 stars. This will definitely make it into our regular rotation.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe tonight.  Husband loved it. My only changes were that I used boneless centre cut pork and I used a green apple infused white wine in the sauce,  because of the boneless pork, I reduced the cooking time to 30 minutes at 350 and then another 20 minutes with the sauce.  I also double breaded the pork using bread crumbs mixed with some garlic powder, Italian seasoning, and cayenne pepper.  The pork turned out great, very juicy and perfectly coloured inside however I did find that pouring the sauce on top and that extra baking did take away from the nice crunch that the breading had as it became a little soggy.  I served it with steamed carrots, yellow beans and snow peas, corn on the cob and some baby red roasted potatoes.  Great dinner!!

text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC & so versatle. I have even used chicken breast instead of pork. It's simply delicious! I add onion powder to the season rub also some diced onion & minced garlic to the sauce. You can add any variety of spices to your taste and you can also substitute the wine for chicken stock, but the wine really adds another level to the taste you don't get with stock. This was an instant family favorite & is now in our biweekly must haves!!!

Display Name:
SLJ

22

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did what many if the other reviewers suggested for the gravy and cooking time. For the gravy I used 1 can mushroom soup, 1/3c wine, 1/2c milk like the recipe states; but I first sauted 4oz chopped mushrooms with 1/4 white onion, and one clove of garlic in 1T butter. I then added salt, pepper, 1/2t (I think) crushed red pepper flakes, and 1T of kitchen bouquet. I simmered it on low for 15-20 minutes while the pork chops cooked for ONLY 30 minutes. I think any longer they would be way overdone. Maybe next time I'll reduce the cooking time to 25 minutes. I served with mashed potatoes and a salad. The hubby loved it! My tweaking of the recipe is the one I will use in the future!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I always love to try out new recipes & this one did not disappoint! I was out of eggs & only had plain panko crumbs so I just seasoned the chops w/salt, pepper, garlic powder, Italian seasoning, dusted them with flour, wet them with water & pressed the breadcrumbs in. I browned them well in coconut oil which cut down the initial cooking time to 40 minutes. I was afraid of a blah sauce so to the soup/milk/wine mixture I added a healthy dollop of sour cream & a few good splashes of Worcestershire sauce. SO TENDER and yummy!!!  This is DEFINITELY going into the rotation, but next time I think I'll serve it over egg noodles. mmmmmmmmmmm

text:
The seasoning and sauce on these pork chops were AMAZING!  However, (and this is a big however) I would NOT recommend cooking the pork chops as instructed.  Putting them in the oven and covering them in foil turned them to mush.  Far too cooked for my taste.  We love pork chops in my house and we couldn't eat more than half a piece.  I am a little surprised that I have not seen this mentioned before. Anyway, I tried this recipe again, same seasoning and sauce, but I just cooked the pork chops on the stove like I normally do, and brought the sauce to a simmer on the stove as well and poured over when it was time to serve.  It was much better!

text:
OK--this was yummy.  Hubby doesn't like mushroom so I used creamed of Onion soup (USE THIS Onion and NOT Celery and use the wine NOT Belgian beer !!).  This might be more salty than the mushroom so I added about twice the amount of wine and about 3/4 cup chix stock.  Only made 2 thick pork chops but oh so delicious.   I could have cut about 20 to 30 minutes off the pre-sauce time.  They were still delicious but fell apart--maybe that's the goal but hubby likes them a bit less done.   I didn't  pour the sauce over the chops, just around them.  What a gorgeous color after 30 min in the oven.  Made this with german Wirsing (Savoy cabbage, Bacon, Onion and white sauce) and smashed potatoes.  super YUMYUM!

I tried this recipe tonight and it was great. Instead of baking for an hour, I baked for 50 minutes. And instead of baking for thirty minutes after smothering them I baked for 25. I smothered each chop about 75% with the mushroom mixture.  Not only were the chops moist, but they had a really good flavor. I seasoned with a little garlic and seasoning salt with pepper the night prior. This was my first time successfully baking thick chops, and I'm pretty proud. I used dried bread crumbs because I like the crunchy-ness. The mister loved it as well!

Also the spices with the garlic powder and lawrays season all salt I added a dash of lemon pepper Yum in the Tummy !!! 
I served with loaded mashed potatoes and Mac
And cheese with a Cesar salad !!!

Baked for 30/30 minutes without and then with the sauce.

text:
This recipe easily goes to a 5-star if you add a can of golden mushroom soup and double the milk to make more sauce. Serve with a side of mashed potatoes and pick a veggie that goes with mashed potatoes. The truth is that you can make the sauce to top your pork chops or chicken breaded and fried however you prefer. I like Zatarans oven fry mix for pork chops, and I'm going to try that next time before transferring the pork chops to the casserole dish to eliminate the frying step, because I'm usually cooking 8-10 pork chops, and that's 3 pans to fry them all! But, thanks for sharing this one!

text:
I hardly EVER make pork chops. They are just too chewy and bland! But my husband had an itchin' for them. So I stumbled across this recipe and was SO glad I did! Wowza! My perception on these has definitely changed. I came across a steal of a deal on thick pork-chops. I used 4. Followed the recipe(flavored each step on dredging). Fried, baked for 30min, added the sauce, and baked another 30minutes. I sauted fresh mushrooms and added it to the sauce. Oh, and I was a little heavy handed with the Sauvignon Blanc! Phenomenal recipe! Soooo good! Can't wait to have this tomorrow for lunch. I served with corn and red-skin garlic mashers. Also, to go with the garlic theme....I got a can of roasted garlic cream of mushroom soup! I will definitely be making this often! This is definitely a keeper, especially for big family meals on a budget!

text:
I made this dish for my fathers bday. It was the best smothered chops ive had. I did change a bit. I bought center cut bone in chops. I seasoned it with lawrys season salt and black pepper, chopped a sweet onion, and let it all marinate for 3hrs. I fried them the same but w/o the crumbs. I put fried chops, onions, fresh mushrooms, and 2pcks mushroom gravy (McCormick) in the pan. Baked on both sides for 35min each at 375. It falls off the bone. Mmmmmmmm.

text:
I made this recipe just as written and it was not bad but not great either and a little bland and super over cooked. 2nd time around I followed a combination of other's reviews and was suprised and pleased at how good it was! I only cooked the pork for 30 minutes before and after adding sauce, doubled the amout of sauce using 1 can Golden Mushroom soup and 1 can cream of mushroom, which makes huge difference in flavor, added a container of sauteed mushrooms and some chives plus a dash of red pepper, for color to the sauce before covering meat . Not only did it come out amazingly tender and with enough sauce for dipping the meat into the flavor was perfect much more flavorful without being too rich would have given my second batch 5 stars!

Bland comfort food.  My husband and son quite liked it, I thought it was just OK, and too much work (and mess) to make considering the results.  I reduced the cooking time by 30 minutes but the pork chops were still overdone.  I probably won't make this again but if I did I'd put more into the sauce, onions and mushrooms at least, and cut the cooking time down to 25 minutes without the sauce and 10 minutes with, or heat the sauce separately and pour it over the chops to keep the breading from becoming soggy.

text:
A very good basic recipe. Perfect empty fridge dinner. Very easy recipe to add to. Say you have fresh mushrooms for example - just toss it in the sauce along with any other complimentary flavor. Also be sure to follow the dredging instructions as suggested. As with any frying use hot oil and set food on paper towel for draining excess oil prior to baking. I've tried this with cutlet as well, just be sure not to overtake (just pan frying works)

text:
This recipe came out finger licking good.  Definitely the Best chops ever.  I did make a few adjustments because I did not want to run out to the grocery store, I just used what I had in my pantry.  Used an assorted pack of pork lion, used 1 can of cream of chicken instead, sauteed mushrooms and onions and added them to the soup mixture, used seasoned batter instead of flour, used garlic and herb bread crumbs instead, used 2/3 cup milk and 2/3 cup of white wine.  I fried the chops first for 5 minutes, drain them, then place the chops in a baking dish, added the soup mixture, cover it with foil, then baked it all at one time for 35 minutes at 350 degrees.  They came out moist and tender.  Melt in your mouth.  My husband and kids loved it.

I had really thick boneless pork chops....2 of them just for hubby and me. country:
None
text:
My whole family loved this recipe! The only adjustment made was to add a can of Golden Mushroom soup to the ingredients which allowed us to have plenty of DELICIOUS gravy for our mashed potatoes. A couple of "happy accidents" that happened were, I burned the chops while "browning" them and I put the soup mixture in the pan before ever putting it in the oven. My burners must not be well calibrated because after 3 minutes of browning at "medium-high" the house was full of smoke and the chops were black on one side. I immediately turned the burner down to "medium", turned the chops over and after 50 seconds the other side was starting to burn. I did not want to waste the chops so I kept on with the recipe and baked the chops with the soup mixture for 1:05 and they turned out absolutely delicious! This recipe will definitely be a frequent flyer in our home but for now on I will brown at "medium" and check them frequently.

We are pork chop lovers, but these were the best chops ever! I used 2" boneless center cut & butterflied them, salt & pepper both sides. I added season salt, garlic powder & old bay to the flour mix & parm. cheese to the bread crumbs. I sauted them crisp and baked for 20 min. I used sherry wine ( a bit more than 1/3 c) in the soup mixture, baked for 35 min. The chops were very tender & the sherry added  a delicious "French" taste! Bye-bye shake & bake! This is a Keeper!

7304133
Display Name:
teresa
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
to give this a bit more of an adult-taste i did the following

1.  while the pork chops were cooking, i sauteed onions and mushrooms in a deep skillet that i used to fry the pork chops. i then removed the onions and mushrooms and added the soup + milk + white wine (I added a wee bit more white wine).  I also added a thumb of good cognac (this makes a HUGE difference, and don't forget all the alcohol evaporates anyway).  I allowed these to simmer for a little while then added back the onions and mushrooms and allowed the whole shebang sautee while the pork chops cooked

2.  i cooked until an appropriate internal temperature (to each their own!)

3.  i prepared egg noodles and, once they were cooked, tossed them in the delicious sauce.  

i thought these small additions made the whole meal extra special!  given how heavy the meal is, i paired it with a crisp gerwurztraminer but i'm sure a riesling would have also been good.  it was the same bottle i used to make the sauce of course.  i would avoid a heavy chardonnay (because the dish is just so heavy to start off with) or an overly citrus sauvignon blanc.  i think beer would have been a good alternative.

Enjoy!

country:
None
text:
Made this recipe using 2 thick 1.5 inch bone in chops. I skipped the bread crumbs coating (hubby hates bread crumb anything) so I only did the egg wash and flour dip. I pan fried for 2 min on each side (any more and it would have been burnt) and baked for 1 hour as the recipe states. I sauted some onions in the drippings and then made the gravy/sauce and used apple juice instead of white wine because I didn't have any. I poured the sauce on top of the chops and baked another half hour. These chops turned out EXTREMELY moist,tender and delicious!!! If you have thick chops, cook for the full amount of time!! It does not turn out dry at all!!! The only thing I'd recommend is to drain the grease before adding the sauce to the chops. I will be making this many many more times!!!

text:
Turned out great.  30/30 min bake time is perfect.  I also took the advice of previous reviewers and added a bit more wine and chopped mushrooms.  As for the fry time, I nearly charred one side of the chops while frying (set the heat way too high) but they still turned out perfectly after baking in the sauce, so no worries about over frying.  Only gave 4 stars because calling for 2 cups of bread crumbs left me with nearly 1 cup of wasted bread crumbs.  Will make again.

country:
None
text:
These are fantastic!  A few tips....you really only need to brown your chops for a minute or two on each side.  Any longer, and they will be charred on med-hi (I learned the hard way).  My chops were about an inch thick and only took 35 mins (total) to finish baking.  I didn't want the "crust" to be soggy so I uncovered them about 20 mins before they finished in the oven and waited to pour the sauce over top until just before serving.  Yum!

text:
What a great recipe!! I never had much luck with pork chop recipes and my husband doesnt even like pork and he loved it!  This is a keeper! One tip that I followed and glad I did was to cut the cooking time drastically....I sauted for 5min each side and baked 20min and then 20 min with sauce.  Also decreased milk to 3/4 cup and increased wine to 1/2 cup.  I added sauted fresh mushrooms to sauce too.  Next time I think I will use Chardonnay to make wine flavor bolder.   I only had a white reisling, but still came out great!!!

text:
We wondered what slamming meant until we tried this. I did not want to use canned soup, so made a roux (butter/flour/chicken bouillon cube and water) and used that. Wish I had made double the amount of gravy, it was so good. Also recommend using the scrapings from bottom of pan to mix in to the gravy before serving it really enhanced the flavor of the gravy (as expected). I also added onion powder to the gravy. The meat was very tender. I would definitely make this again.

country:

text:
This was delicious.  Seriously.  My husband already asked when I'm making it again and we just had it last night.  I made a few changes.  I put onions and mushrooms under the chops while they baked and in my hot skillet after searing the chops I sauteed onions and mushrooms before adding the soup, milk, and wine.  I added a little parsley and seasonings, as well.  The sauce was the star of this dish.  We had redskin potatoes and green beans and the sauce worked well with all three components.  I only baked the chops for 30 minutes then added the sauce and turned the oven off and let the flavors meld for about 20 minutes in the oven while it cooled.  The chops were very juicy, not overdone at all.  The only thing I'll change next time is the use of bread crumbs.  I felt that the flavor of the bread crumbs did compliment the amazing flavor of the sauce.  Overall, really good recipe that I will definitely use again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
In preparing this recipe, I took into consideration some of the other suggestions (e.g. frying the meat until the coating was crispy, cooking the soup/wine sauce in a saucepan separately, adding fresh garlic and mushrooms to the sauce, and reducing the oven time to about 20 - 25 minutes.)

The result?  Although the dish "looked" good, it still lacked flavor and was bland.  It needed more oomph.  Perhaps more garlic or salt or pepper, but it tasted like plain ol' pork chops with breading and mushroom sauce.  My kids and father-in-law agreed with me as well.
I also found that after pan frying the pork and putting it into the oven (without adding sauce), the coating still became soggy.  Why bother frying the meat in 4 Tbsp of oil (fat, calories, etc.) if it doesn't retain the crispy coating and just becomes soggy? 

You would think that with over 3,000 mostly positive reviews, this recipe would be a sure thing, but that wasn't my experience.  I won't be making this again.
Review:

5

userID:
4198478
Display Name:
nonblondmom
isPro:

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1584007.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ARE YOU KIDDING ME??!!!??  These porkchops are AWESOME----even if you don't have EVERYTHING on the ingredient list!  I absolutely HATE cooking pork, I rarely make it and, except for a man-revolt at my house against chicken,I would not have tried this recipe.  I had five boneless pork chops, washed and seasoned them with a pinch of salt,cracked black pepper, a pinch of cayenne and a pinch of paprika on each.  (I had absolutely no garlic in the house) Made and egg and milk wash, a bowl of flour and a bowl of italian breadcrumbs.  Dredged in the flour first, then the wash, and finally the breadcrumbs.  My gosh!  Frying them in the hot oil (all I had was extra virgin Olive Oil) they smelled INCREDIBLE and the coating was brown, beautiful and crispy!   I  put the chops in the oven with a tight covering of aluminum foil.  After about 35 minutes (i used other reviewers cooking times) I took them out of the oven and made a "sauce" out of what I had available---cream of chicken soup.  I added 3/4 can of milk , stirred and put it quickley through a strainer--to get the chicken out(it just seemed WRONG to have those floating on pork)  I grinded ALOT of black pepper--I was maybe trying to go for a more country fried steak type of gravy?   I had NO wine, No apple juice,No Substitute.  Anyway , I poured this over the chops and back in the oven for another 25 minutes.   TENDER! The guys said they were the best EVER! I'm still in shock! I will try the original recipe after shopping next time

userID:

Display Name:
Keith Jefferies

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6402934.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good recipe. I used half and half instead of milk, only because I had some, and I added a bit more wine. The sauce was a little too thick at the end, and if I do this recipe again, I'll create some extra sauce in a sauce pan to douse the chops at the end.

I used Emeril's Essence instead of plain seasoned salt. Gave a tiny tiny bit of spiciness which was appreciated even by the scared-of-spicy people.

Be careful and make sure you shake the excess flour and breadcrumbs, or the breading will be a bit thick (albeit tasty). 

I used more oil than indicated. Using a 2-3 times as much oil browns the chops a lot better with more golden color.

Very pleased with the recipe.

text:
This was such a delicious recipe!  I am not a fan of pork chops, but my husband is.  I look for recipes that I may like so that I can make them from time to time.  The are GREAT.  The only change I made was adding fresh sliced mushrooms, because I happened to hae them.  I sauteed them in the pan after the pork chops.  I added about 1 TBS of butter and a little seasoning.  I was afraid the chops would be dry, but they were moist and, again, very very tasty!  I will definitely make this one again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one's on my rotation. I crave it, even. It's taken me some finagling to get it just the way I like it, though. I double bread them--barely brown once after dipped, dip again and brown slow to just-crispiness. I use flour, garlic salt, pepper and some chili powder. Then I top them with stuffing and pour the mixture of one can cream of mushroom, another can cream of golden mushroom, and some white wine or white wine vinegar and a tsp of ground mustard. gives it its own unique, addicting zing. not too hard to make or on the budget at all. i always make it with mashed potatoes loaded up with cream cheese, sour cream, butter and milk. this combo is usually my stand-in when i want something dense and luscious. :)

text:
This is how I usually make my pork chops all except for the mushroom gravy. I take one chicken boullion cube dissolve it in a small amount of water, then pour it into the pan I'm cooking my chops in. I pour in just enough to cover the bottom of the pan then cover with foil. Makes the chops so tender you can cut them with a fork. We like A1 or a BBQ sauce to dip them in.

This recipe was pretty good. I made some changes and would make even more if I make this again. I followed some reviewers suggestion and used 2 cans of soup - mistake. The pork chops were just swimming in soup. Should have just stuck with one can. I added extra garlic powder, salt and pepper to flavor on both the pork chops and in the sauce. I baked the chops for 45 minutes, poured on the sauce and baked for 30 minutes more and they were perfectly cooked and moist. I don't know, next time I may do what other reviewers did and just serve the sauce on the side.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe! But..maybe it was because I used bone-in chops but the bake time was way too long! After only 50 mins in the oven my chops were already over done I would say bake on 350 for 45 mins and add sauce for an addition 10 mins. So a total bake time of 55 mins. I also sauteed some onion slices,quartered mushrooms, and 2 cloves of garlic in 2 tbls butter and a splash of white wine during the first baking session and then added this to my sauce! The addition really dressed this recipe up!!:) Very moist and flavorful!

text:
I made this recipe a few weeks ago and I am making it again this week.  It is really delicious.  I pretty much followed all of the directions except I used a can of cream of chicken soup instead of the mushroom.  Next time I think I will use a can of cream of mushroom and a can of golden mushroom just to experiment with taste.  I covered and baked for 35 min., heated up the sauce on the stove, then uncovered put on the sauce and baked for another 5 min.  Although the chops were not "falling off the bone," they were very tender and juicy.  I can't wait to make this again!!

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
844597
Display Name:
EKERR19
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
68
favoritesCount:
419
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/255989.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This wasn't my favorite, sorry.  Husband liked it, but I prefer my own unbreaded baked porkchop recipe. I used panko bread crumbs as that's all I had - and I'm glad I did, because I think store bought processed bread crumbs would have lessened the overall flavor and texture of this dish.  I seasoned my chops with ground pepper, salt, garlic powder and Mc Cormick's Smoky Sweet Red Pepper mix. To make things easier - I used my Pampered Chef flour shaker to "coat" the chops instead of dredging - I also used 2 cans of condensed soup so I would have plenty of gravy for rice.  Because of that, I doubled the milk, but used only about 1/2c. white wine.  I found I needed more oil to brown my chops and I used Smart Balance oil instead of olive oil as I don't care for the taste of olive oil when frying breaded foods.  I still found the taste of wine overwhelming and didn't care for it - I used Robert Mondavi Reserve Chardonnay.  Even though my chops browned up nicely and the panko adhered perfectly, the taste of the gravy was gummy and strange.  I would recommend cooking uncovered in the oven - covering with foil really softened the crumb crust and made it mushy.  The chops definitely need more seasoning than indicated - even more than I used.   I also found I needed to adjust the cooking times to 45/30.  If you like this kind of dish, I'd recommend playing around with it a bit but it's just too much work with too little 'pork chop' flavor and a strange white wine after taste for me.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-02-06T14:42:29.517
helpfulCount:
1

text:
I actually tried this with boneless chicken breast first, and tweeked it just a bit.  I mixed the seasoning in with the flour instead of seasoning the meat.  I also used Garlic and Herb seasoned bread crumbs.  I didn't make the soup mixture, but I don't think the meat needed any extra.  The flavor and texture was amazing by itself... and I did eventually do the same thing with the porkchops, and just as good as the chicken! (BTW- I think baking it for 35-40 minutes was just right, an hour would have made them too dry).

text:
After reading several other reviews I tried fixing two "problems" that I saw were a common issue. First with the crispiness, I used Panko Bread Crumbs and they were perfect. I also only baked for about 35 minutes. I made the "gravy" using both cream of mushroom and Golden mushroom....(which it would have been fine with just the Cream of Mush) i spooned the gravy just over the tops of the chops and baked another 10 minutes or so to let it soak in. We served with rice and my whole family LOVED it. The chops were very tender too, which baking can sometimes dry chops out, but not in this recipe.

None
text:
Next time I'm leaving off the tin foil, the moisture held in from the tin foil made the bread crumbs completely lift off the pork. It definitely doesn't need a full hour in the oven--closer to 45 minutes max depending on the thickness. I would pan-fry the pork, transfer to the oven, and add the cream sauce for the last 15 minutes max. This way the crumbs don't lose their crunch. *If you're out of cream of mushroom soup or if you are gluten-sensitive here is a substitute: Whisk 2tb of cornstarch into 1c. of cold milk. Stir in 1.5tb butter, 1tsp chicken boullion, & 4oz can of mushrooms. Bring to a boil, stirring frequently & then simmer for 1 minute. Add salt & pepper to taste.

text:
We enjoyed this recipe and I will try other soups for sauce.  I used a can of cream of mushroom and a can of cream of celery because it's what I had in the pantry and I wanted extra sauce.  Also, my chops had a nice crunch to the outside, even though I put quite a bit of sauce over them, so just make sure you sear them well with the coating on it before putting them in the oven (make sure your oil is nice and hot before putting them in the pan).  Also, I didn't have any white wine in the house, so I just used milk (again, I doubled it) and added some fresh mushrooms that I sauteed in butter to my soup mixture.

This was a very good recipe. My husband isn't much of a pork chop fan, and he loved it. I used regular bread crumbs and left out the wine but doubled the milk. I also added some garlic powder to the mushroom soup gravy. I browned the chops in a cast iron skillet, then just stuck it in the oven and baked them. text:
I made my own version of this tonight and it was great! I used panko bread crumbs to coat the pork chops which cooked nicely in the oven with the gravy. For the gravy I used the suggestions of using one can of cream of mushroom and I used about a half of can of golden mushroom soup with 3/4 cup of milk(I didn't use wine because I didn't have any) and sauteed fresh sliced mushrooms, I also added 1/2 of a chopped onion, one garlic clove and about a tablespoon of worchershire sauce which gave the gravy lots of flavor. I will be making this again, a very good Sunday dinner!

text:
This recipe is divine!!! For those who don't like the idea of using canned soup - you can just make your own mushroom roux by mixing equal parts butter and flour (2TBS butter & 2TBS flour) to a sauce pan over med-low heat with a whisk and then whisking in some milk or cream (1/2 cup to a cup depending on how thin/thick you want your sauce) and a can of button mushrooms. If you want less salt, use unsalted butter :) I thought this recipe was amazing and because I'm a big fan of wine I threw in some extra :)

I've never been able to make a moist pork chop ... tonight I did it!  I fried for about 4 min each side, follow other reviewers and stick close as my chops turned crispy quick.  I then threw them in the oven for just 30 min covered with foil.  Following other review suggestions, I warmed the sauce on the cooktop and simply reversed the wine and milk as I love the taste that white wine gives.  And yes always be sure to cook with a wine you love to drink, makes the dish that more enjoyable!  Overall huge success, only reason I didn't rate it a 5 star is that my hubbie and I eat very few hearty meals such as this!
Review:

5

text:
Just made this for dinner tonight.  Here are my notes: - Forgot the flour (oops!) - With other reviewers recommendations about letting frying a little longer, I didn't pay quite as much attention to this portion as I should have.  Ended up with a few blackened chops (another oops!) - Maybe it was because I forgot the flour, but I ended up throwing away at least a whole cup of bread crumbs. Next time I think Ill measure out less and add more if I need to. - I did a quality check on the gravy before adding it to the chops, wasnt a big fan, so thankfully I had another can of cream of mushroom and tried one reviewers suggestion of substituting the wine with chicken broth.  LOVED the result.  Baked for 45 minutes then added the gravy and put back in the oven for 15 more.  I think if I make it again I'll actually warm the gravy separately and just add it on at the end.  Overall, it was REALLY yummy.  Definitely a perfect dish for company since you can put it in the oven and clean the kitchen before everyone arrives!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe! I did change a few things...I fried the pork chops in the oil until the were nice & crispy, to sear in the juices. I've made this twice - once w/just cream of mushroom, and once w/ golden mushroom & cr. of mushroom, and it is MUCH BETTER w/ the golden mushroom mixed in! It gives it a much richer flavor! In a seperate skillet, I cooked one piece of bacon, then removed to crumble, and sauteed some chopped onion and fresh mushrooms in the bacon grease. (I also added some fresh garlic in the last few minutes of cooking) I crumbled the bacon pieces into the onion/mushroom mixture, and added it to the soup mixture. I believe I reduced the cooking time to 30 or 35 minutes also...these are WONDERFUL!! Serve w/ corn & mashed potatoes for a PERFECT dinner~

text:
I was really excited to try this based on the reviews, but I was careful to read all the other reviews first (there are always great tips to "perfecting" the recipe).  I am giving this four stars and not five because of the gravy/sauce.  Otherwise, the pork chops alone would get 5 stars! Baking time was way less than the recipe states, by the way. The gravy needed A LOT of work . . . boy, was it bland & flavorless!!! In addition to the mushroom soup, I added a can of golden mushroom (like others suggested), a dash of parsley, seasoning salt, garlic powder, sage, and thyme.  I still felt like it could've been improved more, but on the other hand I'm never "fully satisfied" with any recipe!!  Anyways, I would definitely make it again--my husband LOVED it & always says, "Country cookin' makes you good lookin'."

I'm giving this 5 stars based on my husband's reaction to this recipe. I have never liked pork because it has never had any flavor.. just bland and blah. This however had tons of flavor! I've never cooked anything that my husband wouldn't stop talking about for the rest of the evening. Everyone who happened to call him that night he would rave about it to them! I followed the recipe to a "T" except I used only 4 chops (all I had) & added to the rest of the ingredients a can of golden mushroom. As for my review I'd give it 3 1/2 stars... I didn't care for the wine taste (I used Chardonnay). Maybe if I can find a wine w/o such a sweet taste to it I'd like it. Next time I will try it w/o the wine all together. The texture was great and the meat was so incredibly tender, we couldn't even take it out of the dish without it falling apart!!! Great recipe!
