text:
Wow, was this delicious! My kids normally hate pork chops and these were so tender that they thought it was chicken and RAVED over how good it was! I didn't correct their assumption on the type of meat, they ate it, loved it and I was ecstatic. I only made a couple of small changes, one out of necessity and the other for personal taste reasons. Instead of using bread crumbs (because I didn't have any as I thought), I used stove top and just crushed it a little more for better consistency, and it gave it a really good flavor. As I was cooking the chops in the EVOO, I added some minced garlic for a little extra flavor and I doubled the sauce because my family are big "dipping" people. I can't tell you just how good this tasted and how easy it was to make. The sauce was divine and the chops were so tender you could eat it using a spoon if so desired!

text:
wow and OMG...I changed this slightly...I used 4 pork chops w/o bones.  I smashed up oyster crackers for the breading.  I added some freshly sauteed mushrooms and herbs de provence to the gravy and used heavy cream and milk and white wine. I added some freshly grated black pepper.  Then I baked the chops for 30 mins then added the gravy and baked another 30 mins.  I cut up some red potatoes and put them in a skillet in olive oil, added some white wine, herbs de provence and a little finely chopped onion and a dab of dijon mustard.  The potatoes with the chops and gravy were excellent.  i look forward to serving this to guests.

text:
I made this for my family and everyone loved it.  Even my 12 year old son who is not a big meat eater raved about this.  He liked the tenderness of the pork and the flavorful sauce.  I did change up the recipe because I felt the bread crumbs would not incorporate into the sauce.  I seasoned chops with salt, garlic powder, paprika and black pepper, then dipped the seasoned chops in milk, then into the flour and browned very well on each side.  To the sauce I added one can of cream of celery and increased wine slightly to 1/2 cup.  Also, I think baking an additional hour after putting the sauce on will give more tender chops but 30 minutes was okay too.  The longer it cooks for the more tender it will be.

I won't go into details but this recipe is perfect because you can alter it slightly and get amazing (but slightly different) chops every time. Only suggestion I always follow is making the sauce separately. My boyfriend's favorite food is pork, and I hate pork - but I actually like this recipe! Therefore it's become our staple:). The way I usually make the sauce is this though: 1 can cream of mushroom, 1 can beef broth, cut mushrooms, a little bit (not a whole pack) of onion soup mix, and some Wondra or flour to thicken it up. userID:

Display Name:
morninglory1111

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good-- with some adjustments.  First of all, if you don't like wine (like me, but I thought I would give it a try), 1/3 C completely overpowered the sauce.  In the future, I would omit the wine or substitute broth instead.  I also used golden mushroom soup instead of cream of mushroom (also apprehensively since I HATE mushrooms, but it didn't taste like mushrooms at all!).  My final change to the sauce was adding some garlic powder and ground black pepper.  Next time, I might decrease the liquid in the sauce-- it was a little runny-- or add some cornstarch.  It was the perfect amount of sauce for four pork chops.  The only other change I made was to drastically reduce the cooking time.  I browned the chops in oil for about 1 min each side over high heat, then baked the chops alone for fifteen minutes, then baked covered in sauce for twenty-five, and they were wonderfully juicy and tender!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these pork chops and really enjoyed them.    Due to lack of ingredients, I made a few modifications:  To extend the "gravy", I added canned Turkey gravy to the cream of mushroom soup since I didn't have golden mushroom soup as others had suggested.    I also didn't have Italian bread crumbs, so I substituted a house-brand equivalent of shake-n-bake.  Shaking the coating on in a bag also slightly reduced the "messiness factor" associated with prepping this recipe.  I used more garlic powder than the recipe called for, and on the advice of others, I added onions because we enjoy our garlic and onions here.  Also added parsley and paprika based on the comments of others, but I am not sure if I would include them next time.  Or maybe I would skip just the paprika.  I didn't give it 5 stars because I still prefer my pork chops grilled on the BBQ. Not only are they less fattening that way, but also they are considerably less messy to prepare. However, BBQ'ing them doesn't yield the lovely gravy that comes with this recipe.

text:
Oh my snickerdoodles was this good! I've been craving it ever since. Here's the changes I made to accomodate what I already had in the house: -crushed seasoned croutons instead of bread crumbs -sauted onions in the pan after I took the chops out and deglazed with the wine. then mixed all the soup stuff together in the pan and simmered to thicken a bit -increased wine by about 1/4 cup -Used Sawmill Creek Dry White Served with mashed potatoes and it was so good. This has now become my top pork chop recipe. UPDATE: Recently made this recipe again using bread crumbs as the recipe directed and while they were still good, they just didn't measure up to the ones I have made using crushed "Caesar" croutons. The croutons stay quite crisp, even with the sauce where as the bread crumbs got very soggy. Will always use crushed croutons from now on. Croutons also add a lot of extra flavour.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
While these were good, they were not at all the awesome tasting pork chops I was hoping for (and everyone was raving about). Made these for dinner last night. I "mostly" followed Dawn's recipe to a T EXCEPT for these modifications: a) halved the recipe (used 3 thick, top-loin chops), b) prepared enough gravy for 6 chops as directed, c) slightly modified the milk/wine ratios (less milk, more pinot noir), d) added 1 minced shallot (had one I needed to use up) and 1.5 cloves of minced garlic to the soup mixture and e) browned the chops really well, then added to a greased baking dish, poured soup mixture over all and baked, covered for 35 minutes (I was short on time). My bf liked these, but said they had a "cream of mushroom soup" taste. This was a filling meal served alongside garlic mashed potatoes and corn. I don't think I'll be adding this to my recipe collection. I prefer to make mushroom sauce baked pork chops (by JHILGENB) on this site (which doesn't taste anything like canned soup on chops IMHO). Thanks for sharing!

Display Name:
jennbnsf

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty tasty. I agree with other reviewers, does not need so long in the oven. I prepared the chops as described, and then put them in the oven for 30 minutes. I mixed up the sauce in a saucepan and preheated it, so I could reduce the remaining baking time to 15 minutes. The internal temp of the chops was at 155 at 30 minutes, so it was basically fully cooked then (just needs to hit 160). The chops had a great comfort food taste, and the sauce was really delicious. I served it over a wild rice blend. The only problem I had was the chops were a little tough. Perhaps that is my fault, if I had cooked for the whole 1.5 hours, with the last hour in the sauce, maybe they would have softened up. I was worried, though, that any further cooking would over cook them.
Review:
Rating:
5

This was delicious! I used half the chops, but kept the sauce the same. If you use the full amount of meat, definitely double the sauce! I ended up making the sauce a few days in advance (in a sauce pan separately) and by the time I made the chops, the sauce had definitely improved in flavor. I had also added sauteed onions, mushrooms and a few dashes of cayenne. I baked the fried chops for 40 mins. Served with rice, poured the gravy on the side - fantastic! Will definitely make again.

text:
I took the advice to add a little more white wine.  We were short on time, so I just browned the pork chops, heated the soup mixture and poured it over the chops and baked covered with foil for 30 minutes (cutting cooking time by 1 hour).  They were delish!  The gravy was a little thin, which I'm sure would thicken with the extra time.  Next time I will put them in the crockpot for about 4 hours on low after browning.  Definately a keeper!  this one could really be a crowd-pleaser, so easy, so yummy.

text:
This recipe was amazing!  
The only adjustment we made was not cooking it for quite so long....After frying the chops for 5 minutes per side, we put them in the baking dish, added the sauce, and covered it with foil.  Baked for 15 minutes, then took foil off and baked for another 15 minutes.
I truly think that a total cook time of 1.5 hours would have been way too much.
The chops were wonderfully juicy and perfect.
They are awesome the next day too! :)

None
text:
This was very good.  After reading some of the other reviews I did end up doubling the sauce.  For the sauce, I upped the wine and reduced the milk, used 1 can cream of mushroom and 1 can golden mushroom and sauted onion, mushrooms and fresh garlic in the same pan I cooked the pork in.  My only mistake - I made the sauce in the same pan that I did the pork and veggies in and the leftover olive oil may have dulled the flavor somewhat.  I would recommend doing the sauce in a different pan, even though it creates another dish to wash.  I also browned the heck out of my pork chops and cut my oven time down to 40 minutes.  Tasty tasty! Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
First off this was a very good easy meal idea. I starting making this dish before I read all the way through the recipe and didn't realize it said bake for an hour and half! There is no need to do that. What I did: breaded and fried the chops until golden brown they were pretty much done at the point then I put them in the oven with the soup sauce on top of it as recipe says. I did up the oven to 375 and 25 minutes later they were done. I also suggest using thick cut bone in chops otherwise they will be very dry. Over all very good.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1354708.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wasn't planning on changing this, but I wound up making a lot of changes.  I combined the flour and bread crumbs along with garlic, oregano and basil - and put the pork into the egg first and then into the mixture.

After removing the pork from the frying pan, I added oil, a tsp of butter, a little white wine, 1 chopped onion and some chopped celery and simmered until the pork was done.

Instead of cream of mushroom, I used 1 can of cream of chicken and 1 can of cream of celery.  I put the two into a pot along with the milk and wine and cooked on the stove on low while the pork was in the oven.

After 25 minutes, I covered the pork in the sauce and the onion and celery mixture I made and put it back in the oven (covered) for 15 minutes.

DELICIOUS!

text:
Simple enough and definitely moist. Not a huge fan of the cream of mushroom soup, except when it is doctored up. So I decided to try this one. The only thing that made it for me was the white wine addition, but I am glad I only went with 1/4 cup. It was just right.   Personally I think the cooking time is too long. I did mine for 45 minutes, and I had thick chops. Don't expect the bread crumbs to stay crisp. But they do add some body to dish. If I make this again it will need to have a little more doctoring for me. Like maybe some garlic and more mushrooms.

text:
Great recipe, agreeably time-consuming, but worth it. I seasoned 6 thick boneless chops with salt, pepper and garlic powder, and seasoned the flour with more garlic and adobo criollo. I doubled the sauce, using one can of cream of mushroom and one can of golden mushroom, as someone else suggested and served it with mashed potatoes. I was very happy with the results - chops were tender, moist, and had a wonderful flavor.

text:
This recipe is killer! After reading other reviews I was worried about the breading being too soggy, and the meat too dry, but I still followed the recipe almost exact. I only changed by using cream of chicken soup because I didn't have mushroom in the house. The end result was full of flavor, and the meat only required a fork to cut! I recommed not subing the wine like others did. Makes for a fabulous flavor! Used pork medallions, which looked not too great when I bought them on sale, but turned out to be perfect for this dish! This recipe takes away the strong pork flavor that I'm not too fond of. Will definately make this again! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Ok...straight Grandma's house!! These were awesome. My girlfriend and I are sitting right now and I don't think we are moving anytime soon. We followed the recipe pretty much to a T. However, we added about 1/4 cup of flour (to thicken it a little more) into the gravy and heated it through before we poured it over the chops. You don't even need a knife for this one, just bring a fork. Accompanied it with Mashed Potatoes and used the extra gravy for on top of them. This makes a great Sunday recipe because once you prep and start baking you can do whatever else you need to do around the house. I can't wait to make these again!!!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy and very good recipe for pork chops which could be adapted for chicken very easily.  I've made several times and made a couple of changes the last few times to make it easier and quicker.  First, I leave off the egg as it really isn't needed -  the Italian bread crumbs adhere quite well to the meat as long as you've properly heated your olive oil.  I used Golden Mushroom soup instead of  regular as a personal preference and deleted the milk.  I deglazed the pan with about 1/4 cup of wine and then added the soup and 1/3 cup of wine to the pan and finished cooking on the stove.  This method takes less  time and uses only one pan.  Total cooking time is 45 minutes vs 1.5 hrs.  No real difference in the taste.  The consistency of the sauce is more conducive to using as gravy when prepared on the stove.  Nice recipe.  Thanks for the post.

Well, I'm sorry, but we did not like this recipe.  I read many of the reviews and I should have suspected something was not right when many of the people who said they did not like pork, liked this recipe.  It's true; it did not taste like pork chops at all.  One reviewer said it tasted like fried chicken steak, and I guess it did.  Unless you like soggy breading, I wouldn't bother to bread these. text:
Although I like potk chops I tried this with Turkey Chops instead. I live in Philadelphia, PA and they are big on turkey up here, i.e. turkey bacon, turkey sausage, turkey burgers etc. Anyway I followed the recipe exactly except I did use chicken broth rather than wine, I used a bigger can of Cream of Mushrooms and I also added my own mushrooms. I also heated the soup and other ingredients on top of the stove in a pan first then poured it over the chops. 

It turned out so GOOOOOOD! So flavorful, so tender and juicy! Just GREAT! The first time I made it, I made it for myself. The second time I made it, I made it for company he absolutely LOVED it! This was easy to make and easy clean up as well. I am going to make it with Pork chops tonight. I will report back with how it turn out. But for those of you who want an alternative to pork turkey chops is your way to go. I bought the "Turkey Hill" brand.

text:
This is a very good recipe though I had to alter it a bit to suit my taste.  After frying, I only baked for 30 minutes.  As it was baking I sauted sliced mushrooms in a bit of olive oil and butter and seasoned them with salt and pepper.  Then I added the white wine to deglaze the pan along with the cream of mushroom and milk.  I also added a bit of nutmeg and a splash of cayenne and let it reduce slightly over the stovetop.  I served it with a garnish of green onions. (I also doubled the sauce which was necessary to go with my garlic mashed potatoes.) Even my picky boys asked for more chicken ;)  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
These are very tender and flavorful pork chops!  The only changes I made were to use 2 cans of cream of mushroom, mixed with 3/4 cup of milk and 1/3 cup of chicken broth (instead of the wine.)  I also mixed in some adobo seasoning, garlic salt and onion powder with the flour for additional flavor.  Per other reviewers, I cut the baking time down to 40 minutes and then baked for an additional 30 minutes with the sauce.  Very good recipe!

text:
This was the best pork chop recipe I have tried...I browned them really good, then put them in the oven covered for 20 mins, uncovered and put the sauce on and cooked for another 20 mins...although i didn't have any wine, i just added more milk. They weren't crispy like they were when they had finished browning but they were still very juicy and good. I also cooked mushrooms to add to the sauce and added a little cayenne pepper to the bread crumbs to give it a little kick. Turned out really good! will defiantly use this recipe again. thanks!

country:
None
text:
Great, easy baked pork chop recipe without that "I dumped soup on it" flavor. The wine does make all the difference in the sauce, so don't omit it. It did take me about 1 hour 15 minutes to cook the boneless 1" thick chops through, and that may be because I didn't leave them in the pan to pre-brown for enough time. I think I cooked them too fast so the coating got black before the pork got any actual cooking. We also added a can of mushrooms to the sauce and really enjoyed the extra chunkiness. My husband loved this, and he is normally apprehensive about "soup and meat" dishes.

text:
This turned out excellent and was really delicious. I used turkey cutlets (we don't eat a lot of pork) and cream of celery soup because that is what we had. I also used chicken broth instead of the wine. The cooking time was significantly reduced because the turkey cutlets were pretty thin. I basically just heated them through in the oven and then poured the sauce over and baked it for about ten minutes. I will definitely be making this again! I served it will mashed potatoes and peas...YUM!

Display Name:
Corinne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just two for dinner?  I used two 3/4-inch thick bone-in, center cut tenderloin included (whew!) chops for my husband and myself.  I halved all of the ingredients except for those used to make the sauce.  I used a Ziploc bag to shake the chops in the flour and spice mixture, then dipped them into the egg, then tossed them in the bread crumbs in the same bag (saved on dishes and clean-up).  I browned them in a skillet that can transfer to the oven, so that saved on another dish to clean up later.  Result:  the chops were tender, delicious, and flavorful.  The sauce was velvety-smooth, and wonderful over the rice I made to accompany.  The sauce needed a bit of extra 'zip', so next time I will shake in a bit of cayenne.  If I were to make this for more people, I would definitely double the sauce ingredient amounts stated in the recipe.  An easy and very tasty recipe for pork chops!

text:
This turned out great given how 1. cheap, 2. easy, and 3. bland it sounded. It smelled great and tasted better. -- However, I made two subs: 1. used spray Pam instead of the oil (and it turned out great with far fewer calories) - and 2. used cream of potato soup (since I didn't have cream of mushroom since hubby hates it). Like others, I also used sour cream instead of milk and cut the time down some. This is a keeper!

text:
This was so delicious!! My fiance absolutely loved this dish it was so tender.  I did tweak it a bit however: I used a 16 oz can of progresso cream of mushroom, a packet of lipton's onion soup mix, a spoonful of sour cream, `1/2 cup of the white cooking wine, the milk and fried up some fresh mushrooms to add in. It was soooo good and smelled yummy!!
I also used bone in center cut pork chops (used only 4 though) the only problem with this was the bone seemed to chip off, my fiance made a comment that he almost broke his tooth several times - but still said he loved it.  So next time - no bone in!!

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was easy and great. I used 4 boneloss chops and it only took a total of 40min from start to finish. DEFINITELY use the wine!!! Simmer together the soup, water and a GOOD DRY white wine (I used Luna da Luna Pinot Grigio) until it's piping hot. Then, add it to the pork chops once you finish browning them and stick them in the oven for 20-30min depending on thickness. The sauce is so flavorful with the wine in it (reminds me of marsala) Moist and yummy!!

I was looking for a new recipe using pork chops so I tried this one. I am usually sceptical about trying something different in fear of ruining dinner at he cost of meat these days. so, I took the ratings word for it. Well it was a hit.  Hubby loved it and he's not usaually a pork chop fan.  As the other readers said, you can double the soup mixture if you'ld like more, but for six chops, it was fine. I would definitely make it again and have added it to my collection.  I used thinner chops and only loosely covered the pan with foil. It didn't take long to cook at all, within 30 minutes.

My mom used to make something like this, but the chops weren't breaded.  I like the breading, it adds a different flavor to them. These were soooo good!  I'm a big fan of cream of mushroom soup, so I really enjoyed this recipe.  My kids like cream of mushroom soup too, so they were happy!  I doubled the soup mixture, so as to have more sauce, but I didn't use as much white wine as it called for.  The pork chops were so tender they fell off the bone!  I made white rice with them and steamed broccoli.  The rice does goes well with them.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
These pork chops were absolutely delicious!!!  I cut the recipe down to 2 servings and adjusted the other ingredients accordingly.  I browned the outer crust on the pork, and baked at 350 for 45 minutes, then added the sauce and baked for another 30 minutes (covered with foil both times).  These were some of the most tender pork chops we have ever eaten.  My DH LOVED them, I also thought they were great, but felt they were slightly bland - but still good.  I highly suspect that these chops will become a regular occurence in our house.

text:
I was looking for something different rather than the usual saurkraut and port chops and I found it.  My husband LOVED this receipe.  He told me this morning that he had dreamt about it last night on how good it was.  I used bone in pork chops, pinot grigio for the wine and sauteed some chopped onion and finely sliced garlic clove and mixed it in with the soup and milk.  I'm sure fresh mushroom would be delicious but I didn't have any on hand.  I did not have any seasoning salt either so I skipped that and I also put fresh cracked pepper on the pork chops before I dredged them.  I also didn't have seasoned bread crumbs and just used regular with italian seasoning.  This receipe is a KEEPER.

text:
Wow! I am so glad that I found this recipe.  I was in a pinch with only a few minutes to decide how I was going to make the pork chops I had for dinner.  I followed the directions exactly, but I did caramelize a few onions and then added in some fresh mushrooms.  I also used a can of Campbell's Healthy Request cream of mushroom soup and 4 thick cut chops.  The sauce was fantastic and the pork was moist and tasty.  You cannot possibly ruin this dish at all!  The sauce does not resemble anything that you might expect with canned cream soups.  I would easily and without hesitation serve this to guests for dinner.  Definitely a keeper recipe!

We loved this recipe as is, but people who don't like the taste of mushrooms could leave out the sauce or cut it in half.  I added some baby potatoes around the edge of the pan before baking.  Recipe is definitely not quick and easy, but well worth the time preparing.  My husband said he felt like he was eating in a restaurant!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
1184348
Display Name:
KIMAGIRL
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I marinaded the chops for 2 hours (longer would've been even better!)in a cup and half of marsala cooking wine, finely chopped scallions (cuz I had some on hand, reg. onion would've worked too)minced garlic and worcestor sauce! I omitted the flour and the egg and breadcrumb part. There is NO need for these two steps. I still pan-seared the chops in olive oil, about 10 minutes a side, until golden dark brown. I removed the chops to the baking dish, added 2 sm. can sliced mushrooms to the frying pan,letting the drippings on bottom of pan crisp up as the mushrooms browned. I added a dash (or two) of marsala wine to deglaze the pan. Making sure to get every yummy bit of the pork drippings soaked into the mushrooms. For the sauce I used 2 cans of fat-free mushroom soup, 1/2 c. of skim milk (I would've used chicken broth instead if I had had some in my pantry) and a cup of my marinade. I turned heat off the frying pan, before adding sauce mix  to mushrooms. I always use browning sauce in recipes like this. It doesn't alter the flavor at all, and it really makes the color of a dish like this, much more appealing! Add as much as you like to get the color you want. I served this with a side of rotini coated in the sauce for my kids and hubby who need a carb with every meal. I skipped the pasta and had just the chops and french-style green beans. Low fat and Low carb and Low mess!

text:
These were to die for and thats coming from a non pork fan!  I didn't think pork chops could be so tender.  I only used 2 really thick cut chops and kept the rest of the ingredients the same measurements.  Make sure you brown your chops till the point where they are almost burnt....I didn't have a problem with my breading falling off like other reviewers.  I also took the suggestion of sauting garlic and sliced baby portabellas and adding them to the soup mixture.  Wonderful suggestion!  Around my pork chops I had placed potato wedges.  They were delicious and will do that again.  For only using 2 pork chops, I did not have a lot of sauce.  If using rice to serve it with, you only need a little bit.

text:

I browned the pork in the skillet 3 minutes per side med/high than cooked in 350 oven for 1/2 hr. added soup mix, covered and cooked 15 more minutes.  The pork was very juicy and not dry.

text:
I seriously don't know how anyone could call this bland, it was awesome. I made it for my dad, boyfriend and another friend and they all went back for seconds. 
I doubled up on the sauce mixture and added 1 cup of SC and 1/2 a lemon's juice. Also, sauteed some onions and mushrooms to add to the sauce mixture. I served it over Mashed Potatoes and it was great.
This is a pretty fattening recipe but I did use Skim milk, FF Sour Cream and the LF Crm of Mushroom and it was still incredible. Next time, I might try cutting the calories more by just sauteeing in some non-stick olive oil flavored spray...I doubt there will be a taste difference.

text:
This was a good meal if you like cream of mushroom soup. I reduced the baking time. I baked for 35 minutes then added the sauce and baked for another 30 minutes and the pork was well cooked. In the sauce I added sour cream, mushrooms, rosemary, lemon and seasoning salt. I think without these items this would be a bland sauce. I would have added celery but was out of the time but will add next time for an added kick. I also served with green beans and the sauce on the green beans was GREAT!

I scaled the recipe to make only 3, but once I saw how thin the sauce was, I added a can of cream of chicken b/c I like to have extra sauce!  The only thing I didn't like about the recipe was how much grease pooled up to the top of the sauce while baking....it wouldn't make for a good presentation.

text:
Whoever the reviewer was who said you couldn't get this wrong, was correct!  I thought I had bread crums and didn't, so I just browned the chops (nice thick chops!)  I thought I had cream of mushroom soup, and got down to the end and didn't (wow, time to restock some staples in my pantry!).  I used  1 1/4 cups sour cream, mixed with Lipton Onion Soup mix, and can of mushrooms, and it turned out great!  I did put these in my slow cooker, but that's because I was running errands, and didn't want to leave the oven on while I was gone, lol.  Excellent recipe, and definately will add this to our list of regular meals.  I served this up with stuffing, and it was a hit with kids too.

Great!  I didn't measure the garlic powder and seasoning salt - just sprinkled lightly on the meat. Both versions came out fantastic!!  Thanks for the recipe!

Although I was excited to try this recipe based on all the good reviews, I find myself in the small minority of those who didn't absolutely love it.  I followed the recipe to the "T" except that I decreased the cooking time to 30/20.  The flavors were good, but the pork chops turned out dry and the soup turned the breading into mush.  It wasn't the prettiest presentation.  I'd try it again, but I'm afraid given the time it takes to prepare, it may not be worth it.

Display Name:
WANDA L.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading all the glowing reviews, I had high expectations for this recipe, but have to side with the minority that I was pretty disappointed.  I followed the recipe to a "T" and used very thick boneless pork loin chops, but in the end, the breading was very mushy (in fact, separating from the chops) and the overall presentation unappealing.  Taste was OK and meat was pretty tender, which was the only plus, but after all that work and time, I expected an awesome dinner and was disappointed.   Hubby said he liked it, but I noticed he picked off most of the coating and didn't even finish it.  I served with stuffing and a veggie, but neither of us were even tempted to use any of the extra sauce (and there was plenty left)!  In retrospect, perhaps it would've been better without adding all that soup mixture.  Glad I only made 2 thick chops as I wouldn't have wanted any leftovers.  It's perplexing that so many other seem to rave about this recipe, but sorry, I just wasn't one of them!
Review:
Rating:
5

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2000-11-29T14:23:41.123
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
215862
Display Name:
SUNBERST
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this recipe was so easy to prepare. simple ingredients, give fantastic results. one thing i disagree on is the time of cooking. pork chops come in a variety of thickness, and should be taken into consideration. i used the 'america's cut' chops from dominicks- approx. 1 1/4" thick (a decent size piece of meat). i cooked them for the time the recipe called for, and they were a little on the dry side. next time i think i am going with 40 minutes for the initial baking time, and 20 minutes after the soup mixture is added. so i am eliminating a half hour of baking time. the combination of the mushroom soup, wine, and juices from the chops, turns into a great gravy. which leads me to gravy's best friend- mashed potatoes. i served the pork chops over mashed potatoes, which was a great combo...and i would like to add a tip for making mashed potatoes: use yukon gold, they offer a more buttery flavor (leave the skins on, they are delicate anyways), and instead of mashing with the usual butter and milk,  use a container of cottage cheese. it has the same consitancy and adds great flavor and is low in fat. add a little chives and ground black pepper for an extra zip. trust me, this makes for a great companion to these awesome pork chops!thanks for the great recipe dawn!

text:
These pork chops are seriously amazing!! I followed the recipe exactly, but changed the cooking method/time. 
I pan fried the chops until their internal temperature reached 110, probably 3-4 minutes per side. I baked them for 30 min at 400, then added the cream of mushroom soup and milk and continued baking for 10 additional minutes. I served them with blanched broccoli. These are delicious and going in the dinner rotation for sure.

Not sure why this gets so many positive reviews. When you cover the pork chops with the gravy it will turn your crispy crust into a soggy albeit tasty mess. If I make this again, Ill keep the gravy separate or skip the crust.

It is Great! Just finished up. I did listen to others and tweaked it a bit. Hot bacon grease to fry up not thin pork chops, but not fat ones. Browned them til crispy and slid in the oven for 30 min. Some milk and some chicken broth. Added some bacon bits and it it Delicious. Meat fell off the bone.

userID:
2329490
Display Name:
BrewCrew
isPro:

followersCount:
12

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4084450.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had 6 @ 1.5" thick chops.  I would have liked to find bone-in of the same size.  I adjusted cooking times to 2.5 mins (or less) per side in the pan, 20 mins covered in the oven, 45 more mins with sauce.  I would even cut the 20 mins in the oven to 15 or eliminate that step entirely if you have a boneless cut.  Sauce is fantastic. I did use half and half, added more of that and wine to make the sauce stretch. I served with a second sauce of beef gravy leftover from a slow cooker recipe, sauted mushroom and spinach.  Also, edamame on the side sprinkled with salt.  Husband loved it and he is so good at cooking pork chops, so I was pleased to impress him.

text:
This was good. Although I made a couple of adjustments. I didnt have white wine so I used red. I also simmered the wine for about 10 minutes with sauted mushrooms, the mushroom soup, the milk, and a couple tbls of butter. Plus I would shorten the cook time for the pork chops. An hour and a half was waaaay too long. My 2 thick pork chops were very dry. I think half an hour without the sauce and another half hour with the sauce would be better. All around good flavor though.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great BASE RECIPE. You will need to tweak and adjust it based on the size of your pork chops and spices to your taste preferences. Feel free to get flexible.

I drastically cut down on the baking time (I baked for 25/15) and I still felt the pork was a bit dry. Thank goodness for the gravy. I used cream of mushroom soup and used a combination of chicken stock and apple cider vinegar to substitute the wine. Before adding the gravy mixture I added sauteed onions and mushrooms with smoked paprika and a dash of cayenne.

 The dish was so appealing my step Dad who bypassed in favor of his preferred salmon, decided he wanted to try some of the gravy... then he decided he wanted to share my Mom's pork chop!

This is definitely going on the menu rotation!

text:
Good dish, but I think it needs a bit more flavor in the meat.  I think I will season the meat heavier and at least a couple of hours in advance next time.  The only change I made to the recipe this first time I cooked it was to saute some thinly sliced onions and mushrooms in butter and added the other gravy ingredients (double the amount).  I also thinly sliced potatoes and seasoned them with garlic powder and seasoning salt.  I layered that in the bottom of an oblong baking pan.  I then placed the browned pork chops on top of the potatoes and baked in the oven for 30 minutes.  Then I poured the gravy mixture over the pork chops and baked an additional 30 minutes.  I will definitely make this again.

I followed the directions exactly but since I only made 2 bone in chops I cut the coook time in half. I added fresh sauteed mushrooms to my sauce and fat free half and half in place of milk. I topped the chop with fresh Italian parsley and served boiled potatoes and stir fried green beans with it. My husband and I were very happy :)

text:
My husband and I both loved this. I had 3 boneless pork chops,  so halved most of the ingredients except for the sauce ingredients because we love lots of sauce.  Did not use the seasoning salt because there is plenty of salt in the soup.  Also, I covered the chops with the sauce before putting them in the oven and placed a thermometer probe in one of the chops. It took about 40 minutes for them to reach 140 degrees F.  They were tender and delicious and the sauce was excellent over mashed potatoes.

text:
So, this is a pretty good recipe with some variations.  I put a little salt in the flour and the bulk of the seasonings in the bread crumbs.  I prepared the gravy,  on the stove, while the chops were baking (about 20 minutes).  Then, I used apple cider vinegar instead of wine in the mix, and added some caramelized onions.  After pouring the gravy over the meat, it cooked for another 20 minutes.  Those pork chops were the most succulent chops I've ever tasted.  They were excellent on day one.  Day 2, they were awesome!!!  The seasonings and gravy had soaked through the meat. I served this with white rice and mixed vegetables.   My family loves this  recipe!

userID:
2979288
Display Name:
BeachPeach
isPro:

14

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/207434.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to Ketofy this recipe. So instead of breading and flour, I just seasoned the chops with salt, pepper, paprika and garlic powder. Then I browned them in olive oil for the recommended 5mins per side. I put them in a glass baking dish in a 350f oven for the recommended 1hr. Instead of the cream of mushroom soup, ick, I used the fond from the pan, heated it up, and added minced garlic and a tablespoon of Better than Bouillon Roasted Garlic flavor because that's what I had. Then I added a 4oz can of mushrooms including the water and stirred until simmering and lifting the fond from the pan. Then I added some cream cheese and a healthy dose of heavy whipping cream once the cheese had melted. Poured over the chops after an hour of baking and baked for the remaining 30mins. These turned out awesome and low carb! Love this technique and will definitely do them again! Thank you!

Cant say enough about this recipe. Used pork chops that were about 3/4, doubles the sauce. Baked the fried chop for twenty minutes and put sauce on and baked an additional 35 minutes. This is my second time making this. Although I love the regular recipe, today I added a teaspoon of smoked paprika, two sauted shallots and  a pinch of dried crushed rosemary. I have to say it was awesome. Just added another dimension. Might try some terragon in place of the rosemary and a a half teaspoon of cayenne next time.  I think I will try this with all different variations. Great recipe. Make sure to double the sauce.

userID:
8422114
Display Name:
Steve Steed
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2076671.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sheer heaven. No knife needed. Fall apart tender. Used 4 1" thick butterfly chops. Breaded as directed, but mixed in some paprika and ground pepper to the crumbs. Browned 4 minutes each side. baked covered 30 minutes.
Sauce: Sauteed strips of onion till sift and gold in butter. Added sliced baby bellas, chopped shallot, minced garlic.
One can mushroom soup, good dashes of tarragon and parsley, 2/3 cup wine, 1/2 cup milk, 1/4 beef stock. Mixed in sauteed stuff and heated. Poured over chops. Baked another 30 minutes covered.
Truly one of the finest pork dishes I've ever made or eaten. Smoky, rich, flavorful. Have nice bread handy. There was plenty of sauce. I'd give 10 stars if I could.

5

WOW - Want to talk about a home run, this is it.  I can't believe I missed this recipe with all the things I look at on here.
Its fork tender.  I didn't have Italian bread crumbs so I Ninja'ed 2 bags of Garlic Butter croutons I had, lol.  I added a few other seasonings to the flour, salt, and pepper too.  I then made sure to fry them a little longer to have it cooked well as others suggested, then cut the cooking time to 30 min in the oven for the 1st round, then about 20 min with the gravy.  AHHHH-MAZING.  Thank you!!!

text:
This is an amazing meal.  I served it over Sptzle and it was amazing. The preparation was exactly like the recipe.  My only change was the time reduction of 40/30 instead of 60/30.  I also included browned mushrooms and onions in the sauce (just because I love mushrooms).  Someone mentioned the dishes generated - it's true, but you have loads of time to clean up while the chops are baking.  Also, I brown and bake in the same cast iron pan with lid, so that eliminates one.  I only made 4 chops and we had barely enough sauce so I would probably include more sauce if I did the full six.

text:
Even though I dislike greatly canned mushroom soups,  desperation for a Sunday dinner with ingredients on hand spurred me forward.  I used chardonnay for the white wine and eye-balled the amounts of garlic powder and Lawry's seasoned salt. I dredged  my 1-1/2 inch chops as instructed, browned them in an iron skillet using less than the amount of olive oil suggested, poured the soup mix on, covered the skillet in foil and and popped it into the oven.  They were done in less than an hour....and were delicious.  Beware of the recipe's designated cooking time.  It seems much too long.

userID:
12568717
Display Name:
Deb Kacher
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, this was phenomenal!  Pork chops scare me ... big time.  But I read all the reviews and did just a few minor changes.  My chops were pretty thick .. maybe an inch and a half.  I trimmed them, seasoned salted, peppered, and garlic powder rubbed them and put them in the fridge for a half hour.  I followed bdld's instructions for egging and coating (but added a packet of beefy onion soup mix to the Italian seasoned bread crumbs), browned them, and put them in an oven pan and covered them tightly.  I ONLY baked at 350 for 45 minutes.  I used one can cream of mushroom and one golden mushroom, added cracked pepper, Hungarian paprika, more garlic, 1-1/4 cups Chardonnay, and 1/2 cup milk.  It tasted a little bland, so I had some truffle powder left from Hello Fresh and added that.  Delicious!  Always taste your sauce before you intend to use it.  After adding this sauce over the chops, I baked for another 30 minutes.  The chops were spectacular ... gourmet restaurant quality!  I served them with mashed potatoes and asparagus.  Keep in mind ... you want TWO cans of soup so that you have enough "gravy".  You will want it!  Hat's off to you bdld!!!

text:
This turned out really good. Frying on 5 minutes each side was perfect. I sauteed some mushrooms and onions in the pork chop pan  with butter after they went in the oven. I only had one can of cream of chicken soup so I found a recipe for cream of chicken soup online to make more gravy as other posters suggested was a good idea. (It is basically flour, butter, milk, chicken broth, garlic powder, and onion powder). Then I added my can to that as well as the sauteed mushrooms and onions. It made a delicious chunky gravy. The pork chops only needed 35 minutes and I added a few spoons of the gravy over them for the last 15 minutes. I left the rest in the pan to use as extra because I made this with mashed potatoes. We loved this. I didn't change anything with pork chops and seasoning them though. And they were delicious and tender. Thanks for this!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very nice comfort food dish.  This could be a great recipe for someone who has never cooked before.  It would be almost impossible to mess up.  If you don't mind a fair bit of kitchen cleanup due to all the pots, pans, plates, etc...then give this a shot.

I recommend using bone in pork chops.  The only modifications I made was to saute 3 cloves of garlic and 8 oz or chopped portobello mushrooms which were added with the soup/milk/wine mixture.

This works very well over jasmine rice.  Just don't believe the calorie count.  If you are using bone-in pork chops, you only need 3 of them.  And each of these 3 services tops out at just over 1,000 calories despite not using all the olive oil, bread crumbs, or eggs.  I wish it was only 457 calories.

text:
This is absolutely delicious. Doubled recipe and also didnt put the sauce over in the oven. I added it after it was on plate with white rice and gravies the rice as well. Left the pork chops crunchy. Didnt want them soggy after putting in oven so omitted the extra 30 minutes. Timing the cooking time for chops is going to depend on how thick your chops are. I didnt have to cook as long especially after frying.  But this recipe will absolutely eat made again. Great easy dish.

text:
So good! I followed the advice of some other reviewers. Browned the (thin) pork chops until the breading was nice and crispy in a hot pan before putting them in to bake. For the sauce I used one can golden mushroom, one can cream of mushroom, 2/3 cup white wine and 1/2 cup milk. I also sauted some garlic, mushrooms and onion and added them to the sauce. This recipe is amazing. Served pork over mash potatoes and added plenty of the gravy. So so delicious. Will definitely be making again.

text:
This is going to be my go to porkchop recipe. Honestly, follow the whole process for the full 1.5 hours of baking. The meat just fell off the bone. Only difference is I did a little under 1 cup of milk for the sauce and about 1/4 a cup of flour. I whisked it together. The flour helped it thicken and it became more of a gravy than a sauce. I also cut up a heaping amount of mushrooms. I put the mushrooms on and then covered it with my gravy/sauce.

text:
I made these for dinner last night (for the first time). I used 5 boneless pork loin chops which were approximately 1" thick. Therefore, I decreased all other measurements except for the sauce ingredients. Per other reviewers, I added onion powder and black pepper to the chops. I browned them for 2-3 minutes per side, and then baked them in our large toaster oven for 20 minutes. I made the sauce on the stove and added it on top of chops and white rice when serving. We enjoyed it and I will make it again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Good basic recipe for pork chops. I had one huge chop (COSTCO sized) which I used, it was plenty for both of us. I adjusted the sauce accordingly. Season the pork well before breading. I used season salt and extra pepper. I also added lots of pepper to the mushroom soup mix, and more wine than less. Threw in some chopped parsley too. I browned my chop in a cast iron pan and put the whole thing in the oven. My chop was over an inch thick and it was done in about 35 minutes. I added chicken broth to the pan to keep the chop moist. Heated the sauce a bit on the stove, and poured it over the chop for a moment or two before serving.

text:
Alright Fam, you know how it is when you're a college student and you only have so many ingredients on hand. Only "extra" things I picked up were the pork chops and mushroom soup, the rest was on hand...sort of. I improvised the bread crumbs by crumbling ritz-style crackers and adding Italian seasoning, and used chicken broth instead of white wine. Also had only 4 chops and half a chicken breast lying around that I threw in with the rest. And because it was meal prep I didn't even get to eat it until it was "leftover" status. And y'all...it was really good. Served with rice and steamed veggies, the breading just absorbs the flavorful sauce and balances out the dry-ish texture that pork chops can have. Also flavors the rice, I didn't even need salt. Will be a favorite in this college student's book.

I made it a day and half before my congregation potluck and left it in the oven too long to warm up. They came out looking black and burned so I was like "oh well, I'll just put it out and take the left overs home!" THERE WERE NOOO LEFT OVERS. Even the old southern black ladies was ravin about these chops!!! I made enough for people come back for seconds twice (cause I know they can eat). I couldn't even get my seconds  because they were all gone by the time I finished my plate-that what I get for tryne be a gentleman and getting my plate last..... 3 weeks later a sister came up to me and said, "When I look at you all I see smothered pork chops!".....I'm assuming that's intended as a compliment.

Thanks for th recipe

text:
I made this recipe EXACTLY as the author wrote it.  My husband gave it FIVE stars, I gave it THREE stars so on the review I chose 4.  I liked the tenderness and the ease of preparation.  I think next time I will only leave in the oven for 45 minutes instead of an hour during the initial cooking.  Just personal preference but I want the consistency to stay a chop, not completely fall apart and I can't even get it out of the pan in one piece.  The other thing that didn't really tickle me was I found the sauce A) not enough of it. Next time I will double the sauce or half the # of chops.  B) I felt like it was missing something.  Not quite sure what, maybe an herb?  Either way it was still good.  I just think I might do a little experimenting next time.  Thanks for sharing.

country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe. For me, it was an even better base recipe. A great platform which to jump off and make it my own. I didn't have bread crumbs so I just browned my chops instead of breading them. Loved the sauce recipe and I added a can of mushrooms (would love to try this with fresh). The one thing that I changed that really made this extra special was that after I browned the chop,s I sauteed 2 onions in the pan with the drippings and added a little garlic cloves and a splash more wine and put this on top of the sauce after I poured it over the chops. Tasted AMAZING. Will absolutely be making this many times in the future.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1002083.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall an excellent recipe that is simple and reveals tender tasty chops!
I failed pantry supplies so had to go with cream of celery over mushroom.  It was good but I think I'll go with mushroom next time.
The timings must be for very thick chops.  I found the 5 minutes a side in the pan a bit too long (about 3/4" thick chops) and the baking times I cut short as well.  Checked the internal temp after the 1 hour and the chops were at 200F.  I was worried that they might be dry, but the soup and the tin foil I think were key to keeping them tender and juicy,
A little shot of sherry in the soup mixture adds a nice flavour profile.

text:
This is a great dish. I fried the chops fast (Very thin)and  also added real mushroom slices and onion into the frying pot after I took out the Chops for the oven. I but a bunch of extra spices and used panko crumbs in a Italian crumb mixture I threw together. I would just recommend to under salt the breading and focus the salty ness in the sauce. I did bread it twice, this kept the meat tender and prevented in from being over cooked. But it was a little salty. So make sure if you double bread, do not use as much salt.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I am sorry to be rating this with making so many changes, but I didn't have all the ingredients, and was wanting pork chops with gravy for dinner.  Here is what I did.  I made 8 small boneless pork chops.  I doubled the garlic powder, seasoned salt, and flour.  I also added 1 tsp Mrs. Dash onion and herb seasoning.  No breadcrumbs (didn't have).  Kept all other ingredients the same, but replaced white wine with chicken broth.  Dipped in egg and then flour mixture.  Fried for about 4 min on each side.  Baked covered 1/2 hour.  Flipped chops and added gravy.  It was a bit too runny, so I baked an additional 20 min. with cover off, but next time, I will try it on, as I would have liked a little more gravy for my mashed potatoes.  So good!  I didn't even miss the breadcrumbs.

text:
I pretty much followed  the recipe as is and ended up with very nice results.  The chops came out tender and the sauce was rich and flavorful; hard to believe it was just a can of Campbell's soup and a splash of 5-buck chuck Pinot Grigio.  Anyway, be sure to watch (not burn) the chops when frying .  There's also plenty of room for riffing in this recipe.  The next time I make it, I'll probably add fresh garlic, black pepper and maybe some button mushrooms to the sauce; I found it to be just a little bland.  Still, an awesome recipe.

This is an excellent recipe. It turned out the juiciest, most tasty pork chops I've ever baked. I did amp up the ingredients a bit by adding fresh crimini mushrooms, sherry and heavy whipping cream instead of milk in the sauce. I will be making this recipe again and again, and it would be excellent for company. Special note: The cooking time can be reduced substantially. On second making I baked for 40 minutes, could have been further reduced to 35 or so.

I made these pork chops per the recipe, and didn't change a thing.  These chops involve some work, but they are well worth it.  I pan fried chops till brown, then baked for 40 minutes, then put the soup over the chops, recovered and baked another 30 minutes. text:
This was a good recipe; however, not without changes in the recipie as suggested by others.  I added golden mushroom soup to the cream of mushroom soup, more wine, sauted garlic and mushrooms.  If I made it again I would not bread (even double coating when baked becomes soggy), I would simply add seasonings directly to the pork chops and save the calories.  Further, this could be done in a skillet on the stove, simply slowly simmering after adding the sauce.  It is deliciius.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe last night.  It was excellent!  I had 4 bone in pork chops about an inch thick. Browned them in a large stock pan then put the cover on and transferred to the oven.  Cooked for 45 minutes, then added the sauce, returned to the oven for 30 minutes with the cover on. I don't eat mushrooms, so I followed another reviewer and used 'cream of chicken' instead, I had to use white cooking wine.  These were wonderful, sauce was so tasty, chops were very tender.  There was more then enough sauce, some poured over the rice and steamed vegetables. I received multiple compliments throughout the dinner. I will definitely make this again.

My family loves pork, but it's not one of my favorites.  However, I loved this!   I did leave out the garlic salt because I'm not crazy about it, added lots of fresh ground pepper, and used heavy cream instead of the milk.  Next time I'm going to double the sauce because it was so tasty.  I made spaetzle to go with it, and the combo was delicious!!!!   Also, following other reviewers' suggestions, I only cooked it 20/20. . . it was perfect.  My chops were only 1/2 inch or so and I'm high altitude (4200).

text:
I made this tonight.  LOVED it.  My husband said "What is this recipe? Best Pork Chop I've ever had. Restaurant quality.  Better than mom's but I won't tell her that."  I had pork loin chops. I just realized that I forgot to use the flour.  I put seasoning on, dipped in egg then bread crumbs.   I browned them in the pan then put in the oven.  I was a little pressed for time, so I cooked them on convection (325)  for about 20 minutes, put the sauce on and cooked without convection for 15 min.  I used a meat thermometer to make sure they were done. (145 degrees) Turned out great.

Display Name:
Simone Heywood

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3761750.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome  recipe! I did changed  it a little, first, after breading,  I baked the chops on well greased  baking  sheet  at 400C for 45 min.  It's  less work, than frying  and the breading crisped up just fine. Meanwhile  I doubled  up the sauce recipe  and added a  whole bunch of  fresh mushrooms  sauteed with onion and garlic . Then I covered  chops with the sauce  and baked again at 400C another  45 min. It was so yammy! The pork was so tender, and sauce  delicious. I was pleasantly  surprised  how an addition of little   wine (I used Pino Gricio ) made it so much more sophisticated, like a French  restaurant  sauce.  I expected  wine to evaporate, but I could  definitely  taste the wine in the sauce.  It also came out of the oven so pretty  all caramelized  and tender with mushrooms  dotting  the  pork chops  I will definitely  serve it to guests :)
Review:
Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this using many of the recommendations from the reviews. 1) double that sauce 2) use 1 can cream of mushroom and one golden mushroom. 3) make sure the oil is screaming hot to make a dark brown coating 4) Use the left over oil in the pan to cook up some sliced mushrooms, minced onions and at the end a little minced garlic. 5) take this mixture and add it to the sauce and heat it up in a pan on top of the stove with a little pepper 6) only cook for 40 minutes, 20 dry and then 20 covered in the sauce.Came out very moist and flavorful.

text:
Very easy to do. My tweets were to add fresh ground pepper for seasoning the chops. Also keep an eye on your baking times. My chops were not as big as the ones in the video.  My oven runs a bit hotter too, so my adjustment was 45 minutes for initial bake and 30 minutes with sauce.  I also add a little butter in the baking pan to add a little body to the sauce. It worked out great! Have fun adding your twists on this yummy easy meal.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this once following the recipe exactly, and it was pretty good, however I thought it could be more savory in flavor.  I just made it again with following changes:  Used plain bread crumbs, used Amy's Organic Cream of Mushroom soup as it has a much more savory flavor then regular condensed version.  Also used a can of Golden Mushroom and did not use any milk.  I also sauted some green onions and fresh mushrooms in the pan after took pork out and added it to the gravy.  I added about 1-1/2 teaspoons of poultry seasoning for extra savory flavor.  You only need to bake this about 40-45 minutes depending on size of chops, an hours is too much.  It was much better this time and had that savory flavor I was looking for.  My husband loved it.  Served with rice pilaf.  Yummy!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love pork chops so I'm very critical of them as most people are with their favorite foods.  Triple cooking these (once in the skillet, twice in the oven) sounded like a bit much to me but it wasn't, they were AWESOME.  Best bone in pork chops ever and the resulting sauce goes great over noodles or mashed potatoes.  I used Campbell's Golden cream of mushroom soup instead of the regular kind, that gave it a golden brown sauce.  Also I used Moscato as my wine as that is what i had open at the time.  even though its a sweet wine it still worked well.   Also on the first baking, I added a cup of fresh left over chopped parsley I had from another recipe. It was good and cooked by time I added the sauce for the second baking.  So tender and full of flavor, you have to try this recipe.

text:
The pork chops, themselves, turned out as expected, very good.  Seasoning, flour, egg, crumbs, fry and bake is old school cooking and should hardly be considered time consuming and gives great results.  My chops were large about an inch thick and after frying 5 minutes on each side until browned, i baked them 20 minutes to achieve medium rare on a meat thermometer before adding the sauce and 20 after for a meat medium reading.  I added the sauce around the chops rather than smothering them. The sauce/gravy was bland.

text:
Wow, this is absolutely delicious. My son and husband also loved this recipe. I served this meal with green bean casserole, and wild rice. It was terrific. Pork chops were moist, tender, and delicious. You do need to decrease the cooking time; I cooked them 30; then 30 more, depending how long you fry the chops. I used boneless chops, and made my own Italian crumbs with an Italian seasoning,; I also added a chopped onion and two cloves of garlic on top during baking before adding the gravy mixture. YUM!

text:
The only reason I give this 3 stars is because the cooking time is far too long. I brined my nearly 1 pound pork chop for nearly 4 hours, and cut the cooking time down to 30 minutes in the oven before adding the cream of mushrooms.  Next time I'll go for 15 minutes, and an additional 15 minutes covered with the cream of mushrooms. Love the combo though, and made the soup from scratch (Chef John's) with ultra-fresh mushrooms. Served it with steamed green asparagus. A-plus, but there is nothing more sobering than an overcooked pork chop.

text:
Was very good! Pretty easy and inexpensive.

Taking notes from others, I did reduce the cooking time to 30 min pre sauce and 25 min post sauce, but made sure they had nice browning before putting them in the oven. Used 4 chops instead of 6 but kept the sauce ratio the same and that gave plenty for dipping.  I also tend to cut down on the amount of flour and breadcrumbs I see on recipes like this, as even with a generous coating I have leftover bowls filled with wasted ingredients.

userID:
674092
Display Name:
SHRLYANN
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
61
favoritesCount:
279
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If your chops are thicker than breakfast chops there is a chance they will be dryer and tougher.  I tenderize  mine either by  marinating or meat mallet.  Whatever seasoning is chosen, seasoning every layer of the dish will keep it from tasting like meat covered in soup.  Make sure the oil is hot before browning the bread crumb coating very crispy, (do not burn).  For the sauce, I  sauted  a whole onion and fresh sliced mushrooms in the browning pan then added the soup, wine and milk to create the sauce.  As others suggested, it is a great idea to double the sauce ingredients. Add sauce after browning, cover and bake at 300 for about 30-40 minutes, depending on the thickness of the chops.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-06T18:01:55.767

country:

text:
I made this tonight, bf said it was good although he had to add a bit more salt on the chops. I used Silk unsweetened coconut milk as i didn't have regular milk, condensed cream of chicken as im out of the condensed mushroom soup, sauteed fresh mushrooms and mixed it onto the soup mixture. Baked it for 35 minutes as the other reviewers suggested. I added a little bit of the dry onion soup mix, paprika and black pepper on top of the pork chops before adding the soup mixture then baked it for another 30 minutes. Meat came out very tender, if you don't like a lot of sauce though id recommend making half the amount of sauce. Good cook time as you can do other chores while its baking in the oven. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was tasty even though I didn't have all of the ingredients so I substituted alot of things -I used a dash of red wine vinegar and Worcestershire instead of the garlic powder and white wine, added paprika and smoked black pepper as well.  I barely had  the patience with the frying step as I found it very tedious and annoying.    I fried each piece 5 minute then baked it maybe 45-50 minutes, I sprayed my casserole dish with Pam cooking spray & drizzled it with a little extra virgin olive oil as well.  I also marinated my chops for 2 hours in Italian dressing before  I started cooking as I always do this (makes them more tender and flavorful).  I did not have the Italian bread crumbs for the breading so I crushed some Ritz crackers and mixed with flour, black pepper salt & paprika.  It turned out great but like another reviewer noted it made too many dirty dishes and too many steps.  Next time I'll use boneless pork chops as well since my husband picked out bone-in ones by accident.

userID:

Display Name:
josiahlyoung
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined this recipe with the Creamy Herbed Pork Chops recipe on this site and came up with an awesome combination!

I pan fried the pork chops according to this recipe (although I mixed the salt and garlic powder into the bread crumbs so I didn't have to dip as much). I then transferred the chops into the oven and left them at 350*.

Meanwhile, I made a gravy to go on top using 2 tbsp oil from drippings, 1 Tbsp added butter, 1 Tbsp dried basil, 1 heaping tsp of red pepper flakes, and 2.5 Tbsp flour--I stirred over medium heat to incorporate. Then I added a 1 tsp beef bouillon, 1/2 can of cream of mushroom, 1/2 can of cream of celery, milk as needed, and about 1/3 cup white wine. I mixed them all together and cooked down until it was a good gravy consistency.

I grabbed the chops from the oven and served them on plates with gravy over the top. Mashed potatoes, roasted asparagus, multi-grain rolls, and grape juice (a wine would have been nice) made it a meal!

Came out great! I took another reviews advice and made more sauce. I took two cans of CoM and used 1/2 cup milk and 3/4 cup white wine I also added white pepper. I also poured the sauce on top and baked at 375 for 45 min cook time. My husband loved it but does want me to try the other review instructions to bake chops and simmer sauce on stove. Next time! Big time keeper!

text:
Had this for supper with Spanish rice and mixed vegetables (Brussels Sprouts, carrots and a little bit of broccoli) it was delicious and I would definitely make it again! I did make a small change to the recipe......I had some mushrooms in the fridge that I wanted to use up so I sliced them and 1/2 an onion and a teaspoon of crushed garlic fried them in a tablespoon of butter and the olive oil that was left in the pan after frying the pork chops, then added them to the mushroom sauce. I decreased the cooking time to 1/2 hour rather than 1 hour. Pork chops were well cooked, tender and delicious!

I substituted butter for the olive oil- (heating olive oil can change it to a less healthy fat).  After browning the chops and while they were baking, I sauteed some chopped carrots and onions in the butter/drippings then added the wine and soup.  No milk on hand so just went with it.   Added veggies and soup mixture to chops and baked about 15 more mins.  Absolutely fabulous!

text:
Yum!!  Took some advice from other reviewers as I had extra mushrooms in the fridge.  I sauteed them in the pan that the chops fried in and added extra wine when sauteing.  Added the mushrooms to the sauce when baking .  The chops were SOOO tender!  The flavor was SOOO good!  I used Chachere's spice in stead of seasoning salt as that is what I had in my cabinet. Our guests used the sauce over the rice I served.

Fried each side for 5 minutes, baked for 30 minutes, added the sauce and then baked for another 40  minutes.

I don't often give 5 stars but we loved this recipe!  I used center cut with bone in & fried the full 5 min on each side until they were really fried.  I also sauted mushrooms & placed them on top of chops before adding sauce.  I doubled the sauce & added a little sour cream in with the soup.  I warmed  all sauce ingredients before placing on top.  Served these over egg noodles.  I too cut down the cooking time.  A total of 1 hr but next time will cook another 10 min longer or so.  Will definitely be making this again!!!

country:
None
text:
Delicious! This dish will become a staple in my house. As the other reviews suggested, I baked the pork for 35 minutes and warmed the sauce in a pan to pour over the chops when they were done. 35 minutes was just the right amount of time to cook the pork - they were already beginning to lose some moisture. An hour might be good for thicker cuts. I doubled the amount of wine in the sauce (I used a Pinot Grigio, and the flavor of the wine simply was lost in the cream of mushroom before doubling it).

text:
My family loved this recipe. The pork chops were tender and juicy. The sauce was good but not over powering. They complimented one another very well. I only had to cook the pork chops for 2 &1/2 minutes on each side in the pan and then I poured the sauce on after baking them for only 20 minutes. I baked another 20 minutes and tested them with a meat thermometer and they were done.

text:
This is a good recipe. However, in retrospect, I think it could have been improved by using the same skillet used in browning the pork for preparing the sauce, using dry Marsala wine instead of Chardonnay and adding some very thinly sliced green onions to the mix. I suspect that adding a handful of raisins to the sauce would might make it a bit more interesting. I'll make it again.

text:
So delicious!  I skipped the breading to cut some calories, but still browned the pork chops in an oven-proof skillet. I thinly sliced a small package of mushrooms and added them to the skillet before putting the whole thing in the oven for 25 minutes. I mixed the soup, 1/3 cup milk, and 1/3 cup (plus a little more) Chardonnay and cooked for another 30 minutes. Served over mashed potatoes. It was so delicious and felt so fancy for very little effort!

text:
I followed the recipe except for the white wine (i substituted extra milk due to the fact I'm pregnant and don't want to use any alcohol in my recipes). These were probably the BEST pork chops I've ever had. Pork chops always seem to be so dry and these were absolutely perfect! I recommend that unless you're serving all pork chops right away to put the pan back into the oven to keep it warm because i found that the gravy cooled and thickened rather quickly.

text:
Amazingly delicious! I am not a fan of thick pork chops. Plus I only made four as there is only two of us in our house hold. I seasoned my chips with salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder. Plus I only keep unseasoned bread crumbs, so I added the Italian seasoning to mine crumbs. I did brown the chops maybe a little more than I should have on the skillet.... When I made the mixture I didn't want to open up another bottle of wine so I used some pink mascoto and some dried sliced mushrooms and let that sit. I also only cooked my chops for 30 minutes then added the mushroom soup mixture and cooked another 30 minutes. They smelled amazing as they cooked! Plus they came out so tender! We will for sure be making these again!!!

text:
Made this dish with everything called for in it, I just salt, peppered and garlic powdered the meat before the flour, egg, breading process, I also added shredded parmesan to bread crumbs, which were Panko, also added a small amount of sauteed mushrooms, onion, and minced garlic to soup mixture. I used boneless pork chops, browned in skillet then baked at 350 for 30, poured soup, then covered and baked only 20 min more. They turned out very tender and delicious. My son had two and he's not real big on sauces, but said he liked how these turned out.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is good old-fashioned comfort food. The chops were very tender, which is a must for me. Double the gravy if you are serving over rice. The only thing I changed was to cook for only 30 minute before adding gravy (but my chops were pretty thin), and substituted white grape juice because I didn't have any white wine. This was great as is, but it would also work well if  you added flavors to suit your tastes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was uncomplicated and came together quickly. The flavor was just ok, nothing remarkable, but not a "thumbs down", either. I used an ovenproof, lidded skillet to brown the chops (I used the thick ones from Costco), then put everything, sauce and all, in the oven at 250 or 275 for a couple of hours while we went to a movie. The texture of the meat came out tender, almost like a pot roast - I did not have to use a knife to cut it. The sauce was good on rice, but I would say we found this dinner to be a little rich. I will keep this recipe in mind for when I want a no-brainer dinner because of its ease and because I do almost always have the ingredients on hand, but it won't be a "go-to" for us. I noticed that many people are raving about this recipe - I suppose if one was accustomed to eating bland food or cereal for dinner, this would seem stellar, but I think there are better ways of preparing pork chops.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly as written, and I thought it tasted absolutely terrible. There wasn't one thing I enjoyed about these pork chops. The breading was overdone on the bottom, and after cooking was finished, the breading was unbearably soggy. Understandably, I knew it would be soggy after sitting in the sauce, but I expected the breading to at least taste good. It was so unbearably salty, particularly with the addition of the cream of mushroom, and eventually I just peeled off the breading and ate the pork chop by itself. Will definitely not be making these again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great.  Of course, I read the reviews and made some changes.  I agree, you have to wait until the oil is hot and then place the chops in the pan.  I fried them 2-3 minutes on each side.  I only placed them in the oven for 45 minutes. Then for the sauce I used a can of cream of mushroom and a can of cream of chicken, substituted chicken broth for the wine and only used 1/4 cup of milk.  Poured sauce over chops and baked for another 15 minutes. Delicious!  Had enough sauce to pour over the rice w/ the chops.  Definitely a keeper recipe.

I made a few changes to this recipe as an experiment and it turned out pretty good.  I salted and peppered the pork cubes and also added all spice, I then coated the cubes in all purpose flour and sauteed them in veg oil until golden brown.  At that time I added the rest of the ingredients without the cinnamon.  I added a 1 tsp. of Cayenne pepper just for kicks.  Family didn't complain, I live to cook another day.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as it is written...all the same ingredients, nothing else added.  I never make pork, so I was excited to give it a try!  I read some of the reviews and I made sure to brown both sides well before putting in the oven...they smelled fantastic and when they were finished, they were beautiful!  They were Better Homes & Gardens picture worthy!  Oh, I used bone-in porkchops that were about an inch thick.  They were tender and we cut them with the side of our forks...but they were dry.  The breading was awesome and the gravy was really good too, but the porkchops were dry and bland.  We ate them, they weren't horrible and the gravy and breading did help, but I won't make them again.  Mainly I won't make them again because the meat was so dry....but i'm thinking this might be awesome on chicken breasts....buuuuut then i'm just another one of those people changing the recipe!  haha...good luck!

Gluten-free substitutions:
Coconut flour for regular flour

country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner and my family LOVED it. I had to alter the recipe to make it gluten free (rice flour for the regular flour, GF breadcrumbs and GF Mushroom soup) and I used almond milk instead of regular milk. In place of the wine,  I also GF beef bouillon, soy sauce and worcestershire sauce to give the gravy a little less "cream of whatever" dish .  I fried the chops until well browned as directed in the recipe.  The ONLY reason this is a three star recipe vs a five star is the directed cooking time.  I baked the dish for 30 minutes covered, added the gravy and cooked for 30 minutes uncovered for an hour total baking time. An hour and a half in the oven for already partially cooked pork chops seems a bit excessive.  All in all a great dish that my family has requested be put in the regular lineup!

text:
This was really good and simple! I wasn't paying attention and thought the ingredients called for 'italian seasoning' so I added that to the 'italian' bread crumbs and it still turned out fantastic. I also used pork loin and only prepared two of them so I simply cut down the ingredient quantities. I hate doing extra dishes so I left my meat on a plate and hand-pat the flour on, dredged in the egg and then sprinkled and hand pat the bread crumbs on. This was quick and saved dirty dishes, I also used my toaster oven to bake them.  The actual preparation time is minimal which makes it nice to throw together and then do something else for an hour while it bakes If you are not sure about the cooking time invest $3 on a meat thermometer, your food will be cooked to perfection every time. So easy and so good!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had thick chops (about 2 inches), and the cooking time on this was still WAY off. I seared mine 2 minutes per side and then baked for 40 minutes total, and they were overdone. :( That's my fault for not checking them sooner, but the 90 minutes suggested here is insane; no piece of cut meat bakes for that long at 350! Watch your chops carefully and take out when they are medium done as they continue to cook. 

The sauce was delicious. After I seared the chops, I deglazed the pan with the win - make sure you do this! It picks up so much flavor! I used more wine than called for (about double), the added the cream of mushroom soup, and sour cream instead of milk. I used a little milk to thin down the sauce. 

Very tasty despite being overdone!

text:
This recipe is absolutely fantastic. Normally I don't like reading and/or writing reviews when substitutions are made before trying the actual recipe as written, but for this one it doesn't matter. Made the first time as written, and the pork chops were the moistness and most tender pork chops I have ever had bake. The next time I made it we had company that did not want anything with alcohol in it, so I substituted 1/3 cup apple juice (with 1 teaspoon vinegar mixed in) for the wine, and I thought this tasted even better. The next time I made it I substituted 1/3 white grape juice (with 1 teaspoon vinegar mixed in) for the wine, and it was still great. When I make this, there is no need to get out any knives, a fork is all you need. Cleanup is a little messy though.
