city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading thru the list of ingredients I could see that additional spices were needed. I seasoned my chops with paprika, crushed rosemary leaves, minced garlic and course ground pepper. I wan't quite sure about the breading process but in all fairness to the author and in order to review this recipe, I breaded my chops. As other reviewers said 5 minutes of browning is too much. It smelled great but my breading started to burn after 2 minutes. I think it would be better to brown the chops in a very hot oven (425 to 450 degrees) for 15 to 20 minutes then reduce oven temp to 350 degress and finish baking them for about 30 minutes. Too much mushroom sauce. I would drizzle sauce ontop of chops after baking time. This recipe is not so quick and easy. Too many steps that led to ALOT of dishes. With that said, I will go clean my kichen now.

text:
Made this last night and it was really good! The whole family liked it! I baked the pork chops for 30 minutes covered (they were thin chops). I think the time listed in the recipe is way to long. I made the soup/wine mix on the stove and we used it as more of a pour over gravy instead of baking it all together. I liked the idea of the chops staying a little crispier. Overall a tasty meal!!

text:
These were great!  Very rich and satisfying.  I decided to switch amounts and go with 1/2 cup wine and 1/3 cup milk instead, and it gave it a great depth of flavor, I think.  The only trouble I had was that the oil ended up being a bit too hot on medium-high heat, and I burned one side of the chops.  I turned down to medium, and the second side came out just fine.  Next time, I would keep the heat down to medium for the frying.  Other than that, fantastic recipe!

text:
Like most people I didn't follow this exactly. My porkchops were in a bag thawing and seemed wet enough, so I seasoned them and poured in a ton of seasoned breadcrumbs; no flour or eggs. Then I fried on the stovetop and made the gravy separate. The pork chops were plenty cooked, so I didn't bother baking them. The porkchops themselves were five stars. They were delicious and so easy this way! I wasn't very pleased with the gravy, so I'll do something different next time (reason why only 4 stars). I'm making the porkchops again today! Yummy.

text:
This really was good.  I used boneless, center cup chops and they were SO moist and tender.  These chops, mashed potatoes and fresh green beans made for a fantastic dinner.  Be sure to REALLY season the chops before you dredge/dip them or they'll be bland.  I seasoned the flour as well.  The 'gravy' going in was bland, but after it cooked with the juice from the chops in the oven, it was great.  When I put them in the oven, I also added a whole sliced onion...YUM!  I tried this again, but with chicken (and added onions and sliced mushrooms) and had the same great success.

text:
This was a hit in our house! I did as others suggested and added golden mushroom soup as well as the cream of mushroom soup. I added a few more spices to make sure it wasn't bland, and sautee'd red onion and mushrooms, poured on top of the chops before adding the gravy.  I think the secret is to use a very dry white wine.... otherwise a sweet wine could overpower the dish.  Only gave it 4 stars cuz I changed it up a bit due to other reviews.... but it was a really great base to start with!  Thx for sharing! :)

text:
I'm not sure if my review is deserved or not because of all the changes I made, but what I made was delicious!  I usually don't make any major changes to a recipe before trying the original, but I thought the ones I made were necessary. First, I used half bread crumbs and half potato flakes because I think it makes the breading more flavorful. I also cooked the gravy separate so the pork would not get soggy. Lastly, I do not allow wine in my house so I substituted the wine with a half can of cream of chicken soup and 1 tbs of rice wine vinegar.

text:
I was a little worried because once I started making these I realized I didn't have cr. of mush. soup. I used a jar of Heinz Pork Gravy instead and mixed that with the milk and they still came out delicious. I did have to thicken up the gravy after the baking time, so I'd recommend less milk or just be ready to use some flour. I did omit the wine as well.   Our 2 yr. old ate half a pork chop herself!! Considering how fussy she is, that's saying something! A++++ recipe!

text:
I wanted to make a good pork chop recipe.  This got such good reviews I thought I'd try.  The only think I did differently as per many suggested was that I also used golden mushroom soup with the can of regular mushroom soup.  I followed the recipe pretty closely, but shortened the baking time by about 1/2 hour which was a good idea or they would have been overcooked.  My family didn't like them at all.  Not great pork lovers, but I, who enjoys a pork chop now and then, did NOT like this recipe either.  WAAAY to rich.  I wonder if cutting back on the soup (I used two as suggested) might would have helped)..and the breading, rich, just too much going on.    The chops were nice and tender, but eh, overall overwhelming. Guess who ate pork chops all week for lunch?  That wold be me...with a lot of the sauce and breading removed.  I won't make this again.  I gave it three stars because it wasn't HIDEOUS and the chops were tender and if you like this kind of thing, then go for it.

This is a awesome recipe thank you so much you are a life saver, there's only so much you can do with pork chops and to find something new that even kids will eat is a real treat

I don't like pork chops, nor does my stepson, but my husband really does.  He is a picky eater, but he liked this alot.  We would make it again (for him) but I would omit the white wine - I did not care for that taste. I also have heard that cooking pork chops in the crockpot makes the meat a lot more tender (just falls apart).  I think I would like that more.  But, for what it's worth, this was really great if you like pork chops done this way and the white wine taste.

text:
These chops were EXCELLENT!  My family and I don't eat pork so of course we substituted with turkey chops instead.  I didn't have any italian-style bread crumbs so I used what i did have...Peperidge Farm herb seasoned stuffing.  It was a wonderful sub.  Just as other reviewers, I only baked the chops for approx. 35 min.  This was plenty of time.  I sauteed mushrooms and shalots on the stove top to add extra umph to the gravy.  Thanks for this recipe.  Caution:  Very rich.  Lessen the milk if your looking for a not so heavy meal.

text:
This is a winner!  I had 8-1 inch thick boneless loin chops.  After browning them nicely I baked them for 45 min and they were done perfectly.  I put 4 in a glass dish and 4 in a metal pan to bake and the ones in the glass dish were better.   I heated the gravy on the stove because I didn't want it in the pans with the chops.  I used 1 can of Cream of Mushroom and 1 can of Golden Mushroom with the wine and it turned out deliciously.  It made a lot more than we need but we'll find something to use it on I'm sure.

userID:

Display Name:
Linda B.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious!  My husband loves pork chops, but not my son, so I used thick boneless chicken breasts instead -- they turned out so moist and tender.  I did cut the baking time down from an hour to 45 mins, at 325 instead of 350.  I upped it back to 350 for the 30 minutes the sauce cooked, though.  I also doubled the amount of sauce, since my guys go way overboard with the gravy!  The only other thing that I did different was that, while the chicken was baking for the 45 mins, I slow-fried (in butter) an 8 oz. package of portobello mushrooms until they were nice and brown, then added the two cans of soup, the milk and wine to the pan with the mushrooms.  The fried mushrooms gave the sauce a nicer brown color, and brought out the flavor of the cream of mushroom soup.  I used 6 very large chicken breasts, and this was so good that it did not last through two meals!!!

text:
I rated this a 5 star for the taste alone.  As someone else mentioned, it DOES make a lot of dirty dishes and take some time to prepare; but, if you as me, it was really worth it.  Everyone in my family loved it, even my kids.  My picky 9 yr old son even ate seconds of it.  I didn't change the recipe at all, but I DID change the cook times.  I set the oven to 425 and cooked for 40 minutes...then after adding the sauce I only cooked for 15 more minutes.  I did this because the chops were pretty much cooked when we fried them up for 5 mins on each side (which 5 mins isn't entirely necessary either)  I cooked broccoli and fried okra with this meal as well, which turned out to mix well with the chops.   The chops came out very tender and we could almost cut with a fork.  Served leftovers as sandwiches and those were good too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe twice already.  The first time I had thin in-bone chops and was looking for a recipe because my chops always turn out too dry.  For this recipe I would not the thin chops again.  I bought some very thik boneless chops the second time and added a little Cayenne Pepper to the Italian bread crumbs.  It's only my husband and me so I only cooked 2 chops (cut as much fat off as possible) and only used 1/2 can of soup and used Sherry instead of wine - but I still used 1/3 cup of the Sherry.  I also cooked for 20 minutes and then added the soup mix and cooked for 15 minutes longer ...this proved to be too long.  Next time I will cut the oven time to only 30 minutes total - heating the soup mix first and adding it half way thru - the chops should be about 160/170 degrees when done otherwise they get too dry (pork should be a little pink.)  The Sherry is what makes this recipe even more YUM!!!!!!!!  THIS ONE IS A KEEPER!!!!!

text:
This was so delicious and tender. I actually didnt have canned cream of mushroom so I made my own with some pork gravy seasoning thickened with flour, sauted onions and baby bellas and left out the wine. I added heavy cream about 5 minutes before covering the pork with it. I also was short on time so after I sauted the pork on both sides, I covered with foil and oven baked for 30 minutes, added the gravy mix and then covered and backed for another 20. They came out moist, tender and absolutely fabulous.

country:

text:
I only rated this 4 out of 5 stars because I did make a few adjustments.  I made this for dinner last night and it was SO GOOD!  My husband was a little unsure about the gravy at first, but was pleased in the end.  I used huge butterflied boneless pork chops that were still an inch thick.  To the flour, I added garlic and onion powder.  I didn't have enough italian bread crumbs, so I added a can of fried potato sticks crushed up.  I fried the outside until nice and golden brown and super crispy, then baked in covered 9x13 for 45 minutes.  For the gravy, I didn't have any cream of mushroom, so I used cream of chicken, milk, chardonnay, and more garlic powder.  Baked for another 25 minutes.  It was fabulous.  Some of the most tender and flavorful pork chops we've ever had.  Served with mashed potatoes and green beans cooked in beef bouillon, garlic, worcestershire, and salt.  Delish! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I usually avoid any recipe that calls for canned cream of mushroom soup, but I just had to try this because most of the reviews said that the meat  was so moist. This recipe did not disappoint! It's very easy to prepare and makes the house smell wonderful! I used thick pork loin chops and cooked for about 45 minutes, then covered with the mushroom sauce, then baked for another 15 minutes for a total baking time of 60 minutes. The pork was very moist and flavorful! The only thing different that I did was to add garlic salt,  onion salt and fresh ground black pepper to the breadcrumbs before dredging the chops in them. Great recipe for moist pork chops!

text:
This was so good!!!!   I made this lastnight and as I was browning the chops it immediately smelled wonderful.  I was a little concerned about the gravy part; I don't drink a lot of wine and used a cheap one I had bought for another recipe.  As soon as I poured it on the pork chops, the wine was ALL I could smell and I feared I had ruined the meat.  BUT, not so, it was delicious.  I only cooked it for 20 additional minutes instead of 30.  I just felt that they were plenty done.  The pork chops were so tender.  I did use boneless meat.  My kids are really picky and I split one of the chops between the two of them and they ate it all!  I will be making this for sure again.  Thanks so much!

This was some pretty good stuff. I am not a big fan of cream of whatever as I have gotten older. This was a simple quick meal. I followed everything to a T except I forgot to flour the chops and mine did not take the stated 1 and a half hours to cook. Total time took 30 to bake and 15 with the sauce/gravy. I ran out of time to cook so I pulled the pan out and set it on the burner (from my corn) for a few minutes and let the sauce get all bubbly. The taste was right on for an easy cook meal. Thank you.

text:
As is I'd rate it a 1 star, bland and over cooked. Please note all of the 5 stars that modified the heck out of this recipe.  I'd don't consider this a recipe just a suggestion.  Use this as a jumping off point for your own creation and you will also be rating it a 5 star.  I used cream of chicken, poultry seasoning, paprika and shredded cheese. I did the sauce on the stove top and cooked the chops until 155 in the oven. But it is fast and all you really need are white wine, pork and a cream of something soup to make it work. So for me its a keeper with my modifications.

DELICIOUS!!!! I made it overall like the recipe stated. The wine that I used was pinot grigio and I added a little extra because of reading other reviews.  I also added the milk, one can of cream of mushroom, paprika, cayenne pepper, and black pepper. I made the sauce mixture on the stove at low heat, so I could have sauce to pour on top at the end of baking. I only baked it for 35 minutes covered and then poured the mixture on top and recovered it for another 30 minutes. This is not a quick recipe so be prepared to be in the kitchen for a while.

Plan to add pork gravy and use it on a roast for gravy (this should make the gravy creamy). text:
Husband liked it but wasn't the best. followed the directions to a t, but it just wasn't his favorite. Def make it with mashed potatoes and gravy. Might consider making this again.

UPDATE: March 2013: Did like other reviewers suggested and browned well. Then covered and cooked for 35 mins. I checked the internal temp and it was actually a little high so I didn't even need to cook it that long. Then let them sit and made the sauce in a pot on the stove. Took about 20 mins to cook down to right consistency. I suggest taking the chops out of the pan and keep warm on a plate because they will get soggy if left in the pan with the grease.

text:
this recipe is really good and the sauce by far makes the recipe.  I doubled the sauce and used 1 can of condensed cream of mushroom soup and one can of golden mushroom soup to give it extra flavor.  I also used mushrooms and green onions to give it more texture and color.  Since i doubled the soup mixture I was able to spoon about 1/4 of the mixture on the porkchops after letting them back for 35 minutes.  I then took the porkchops out after another 30 minutes and let people put extra sauce on them. delicious!

text:
I thought this recipe was pretty good.  I followed advice of other users and added a can of golden mushroom soup mix, but I did not increase the milk or wine so it was a little thick. Next time I will definitely add more milk and wine because this is a sauce that we wanted more of!  Another change I will make next time is using boneless pork chops.  If I would have made these changes this time I would have given it 5 stars. My very-finicky teenage daughter loved it as was, and she declared that this would be one of the recipes she would want to add to our "Family Favorites Cookbook."  This is a VERY tasty recipe. A definite notch or two above your average smothered pork chops.  I think the wine gives it that little bit of extra zing that pushes it over the top.

text:
Oh My, these chops were fantastic! I did cut the cooking time down to 1 hour. The chops I used were very thick, so I cooked 30 min. on each side. I do think if I had cooked as directed, they would've been dried out. I added the soup mixture to the skillet where I had browned the chops, and cooked until heated. I topped chops with gravy just before serving. Next day, I scraped breading off left over chops, and made stroganoff. The flavor was incredible! Thanks for sharing.

I just made these for my husband and myself for lunch. They were GREAT!! Because there are only the two of us I only used 2 porkchops but the full can of mushroom soup as we like gravy on our baked potato. There was only about a 1/2 cup of gravy left but my husband requested I save it for our potatoes tonight. The only thing I did different was I did not have any chardoney on hand so used white merlot instead and I did not have any bread on hand so I crushed some crackers and added some Italian seasoning to them before I breaded the chops. This is deffinately a keeper!

This recipe was pretty good. No way is the cooking time right though! I cooked my chops for 30 minutes and even that was almost too long! Good flavor though! Good base recipe.
update: I made this again last night, fried my chops for about 10minutes and baked for 20. They were cooked perfectly. I think the problem with the cooking time may be due to varying thickness of chops. I love this recipe. I followed another reviewer this second time and used one can cream of mushroom and one can golden mushroom. I also sauteed some mushrooms and onions and added those to the chops with the sauce.

text:
Easy to prepare taste decent and can use a bit more flavor. The one hour baking time render the meat a bit dry for my taste, therefore i would suggest 30 minutes of baking before adding the soup mixture and 30 minutes after that. Also doubling the cream of mushroom mixture is a really good idea if you have rice or mashed potato going with it. I like corn so I even added a can of corn in the soup mix... Well, it's up to you but generally this is an awesome recipe. Enjoy :-)

text:
Using only 3 chops, I kept the full amount of gravy ingredients... glad I did. I served it with cooked thick pasta noodles and we used every bit of gravy. My changes were: Used cream of chicken soup, 1/3 cooking sherry, not white wine, and Montreal steak seasoning for the seasoning salt.  ALSO added the Montreal seasoning to the gravy as I whisked it, plus a little more black pepper. My chops were average, not thick, and 25/25 baking time worked for us.  My husband is demanding weekly servings of this one.  I threw out all my other pork chop recipes! Definitely DO the breading step, and no, it isn't "crunchy" but gives it lovely texture!

text:
Absolutely sensational.  I added 2 tablespoons of onion soup mix to the bread crumbs.  I had no cream of mushroom soup so I had to used cream of celery.  It worked out fine.  I used one can of cream of celery and then doubled the milk and wine measurements.  I had no pork chops just a tenderloin.  So I cut the tenderlion to resemble chops.  I didn't have to cook it as long since it was boneless.  So yummy.  I also added one 14 ounce can of mushrooms on top of the chops before I threw  on the soup/milk/wine mixture.  Covered and cooked for about 45 minutes. I made sure I sauteed the chops until crispy before putting in the oven.  I COVERED my chops.  I think that keeps it from drying out. Thanks.

text:
Made this for Easter dinner and it was hit. I used very thick pork chops and forgot to buy wine so I used a little over a quarter cup of brandy with the mushroom soup added sauteed mushrooms, then two pears sliced and peeled that were not soft yet aroung the edges of the dish. I did not know if the pears would work with the mushroom sauce so I kept the added mushrooms more in the middle over meat and the pears around the edges of the dish and it worked perfectly.

text:
I made this tonight and I took some other reviewers suggestions.  I switched the amount of wine in the recipe with the amount of milk (I used 1%). I browned the pork chops in bread crumbs, garlic and pepper for five minutes on each side. I then cooked the pork chops at 350 for 40 minutes.   After 40 minutes I added asparagus and the sauce mixture.  I then cooked it for 30 minutes. The pork came out perfect and was very moist.  My husband and I really enjoyed it.  It is a very easy recipe and I will definitely make this again. Thank you!

userID:
3606214
Display Name:
Rachel Swiger-Imhoff
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
117
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5892824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the best Pork Chops that I've had in a very long time. I made a few changes to the recipe, though, as I went. I added just a little bit of chicken broth to the soup mixture, squeezed one lemon and added the juice to it and seasoned it to taste (The way that I usually enjoy seasoning my meats). I also sauteed mushrooms and onions and added them to the soup mixture just before pouring it over the Pork Chops.  I also reversed the amount of milk and wine... Using 1/3 cup of milk and 1/2 of wine, which definitely had a large impact on the flavor. The wine in this recipe is one of the most important ingredients, giving the chops the flavor that makes this recipe so fantastic. I used a cheap chardonnay (About $4 or so for the bottle) and it was perfectly fine for this, no sense in spending more than you have to.   I'll definitely be making this recipe again... It was so delicious, the chops so tender.

userID:
433531
Display Name:
DiablosMom
isPro:

followersCount:
5

0

187
favoritesCount:
274
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a big fan of cream of mushroom soup, but was looking for an easy pork chop recipe and based on the huge number of reviews tried to give this one a try.  Wow!  It was way better than I expected it to be!  The pork chops were as tender as pulled pork, and the sauce was very appetizing.  I took some other reviewers' suggestions: used cream of mushroom with roasted garlic soup, added a can of golden mushroom soup, used about double the wine and about 1/3 cup of milk, and sauteed some onions and sliced mushrooms in the pork chop pan while the chops were baking and added those to the sauce.  I baked everything for about 45/45.  I think there's a lot of flexibility in how long you need to cook it for, so you could go shorter if you need to, or longer wouldn't hurt it.  Served this over rice with lots of gravy on the rice and a veggie on the side.  I will definitely add this as a regular meal.

text:
My 8+ year old loved this as well as my husband.  I did add extra garlic and seasoning salt to the pork steaks.  Then dredged them in flour before the egg bath and the breadcrumb mixture.  This really helped to make the chops extra crispy.  I sauteed them longer than the recipe called for and then baked in the oven approximately 30 minutes.  I then deglazed the pan with sliced white onions, sliced mushrooms and white wine.  I then added the milk and cream of mushroom soup. This was a great recipe for a tender pork meal.

text:
Thank you for this great recipe... We will be fixing this in our home on regular basis. It did not take as long as I thought it would. I even made it on a Tuesday night without planning. I pretty much followed the instructions provided. I would advise that you keep an eye on the pork chops when frying. Directions stated to cook on each side for 5 min on med high heat. Well, after frying chops 3 min the breading was burned so I just flipped the chops. Once they were a nice golden brown (on one side) I placed the chops in the oven to bake. (Portion sized for 2) I doubled up on the cream of mushroom and it was absolutely delicious. Next time I will try it with cream of chix.

text:
I took this recipe and used it to my advantage. I ruined some boneless porkchops earlier, so I took them and sliced them thinly and put it in a frying pan. Then I took minced garlic, ground peppercorn, ground sea salt and seasoned it(a lot). Took diced onion, and mushrooms and sauteed it. Then I took a can of cream of mushroom soup mixed with 1/2cup of milk and added it to the meat. Served it over a baked potato.( I also added a few dashes of rice vinegar to the soup, because I didn't have white wine. Not sure it did anything though.)This was an amazing meal and I will be making this again!

Followed exactly except used c.o. chic and c.o. onion soups, doubled sauce (didn't need to) and I used 3 thick boneless chops.  It was good, maybe a tad too much wine, I used Merryvale chardonnay, which is about $30 a bottle.  Maybe depends on the wine so next time I'll half it and then add more to taste.  Next time I will also cook the sauce in the same pan in which I fry the chops, and keep seperated until ready to serve.  The breading just fell off the chops and you might as well not even bother and just sear them and then cook in the sauce if you do not care to have the breadcrumb coating.  Otherwise keep sauce and chops seperated until serving.

text:
This was really good. surprisingly good! I didn't have any white wine, so I used vermouth. And I have to agree with other reviewers who said the wine/vermouth is key to the flavor. I would definitely not leave it out. I doubled the sauce as other reviews suggested, and found that was too much. This is our new pork chop recipe. Definitely worth the time. Thanks! update 7/3/11- I made this tonight, but sauteed onions and mushrooms in the pork oil before adding soup, milk, and chardonnay. Very good. I didn't combine the sauce and the pork in the oven since I had kids who didn't want the sauce - and I think it's better combined. Just be sure not to overcook the pork.  Delicious with buttered egg noodles.

We liked this recipe. It was a little bit of prep but not too bad.  The only change I made was to use half the wine it called for.  Wine can overpower a sauce so what I do is add less than what is called for and taste test till it is the desired strength.

text:
Awesome and easy to make! If you get to cut your own chops you can choose how thick you want them. I cut them thin (from a big pork roast chunk) and it didn't take long to brown and bake. Very juicy and tender! Breading really keeps pork from drying out and tastes delicious! Sauce may be served separately instead of baked with the chops but this is personal preference. Overall, excelent recipe! Will make often!

text:
This is an excellent recipe and is very easy to do.  I used a 1-1/4 inch thick 1/2 pound boneless pork loin (one meat eater in the family) and followed the instructions exactly.  I only had to brown the coating for 3 minutes a side until it was a very nice brown color, but I did cook for 1 hour and then for 30 minutes.  I made 1/2 the sauce recipe which turned out to be just slightly too much.  Wonderful flavor, beautiful color!

text:
Generally speaking I hate pork chops, however I made this the other night and decided to give it a go. 

I didn't have any white wine and didn't want to substitute with broth, so I followed a suggestion of using Worcestershire sauce, and added in a tsp of Dijon mustard as well.  

I also sauted some thick chopped mushrooms and onions in the oil from the pork and topped it with during that last 30 minutes of baking.  

It was so great!  My kids loved it, my husband finished it off.  This recipe will certainly be reused!

text:
Hands down, our favorite way to have pork chops now!  I made a few changes to the recipe though.  I didn't bother with the flour as it didn't seem necessary. I skipped the part where it says to bake for an hour before adding the sauce - instead I covered them with the sauce and topped the dish with more of the breadcrumbs before putting in the oven.  Baked for 15 minutes then broiled for 5.  Top was golden and the chops were cooked perfectly!!  Definitely recommend keeping the wine in the recipe - it's what makes the flavor!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/42517.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This would have been better if I used a better cut of meat. I used "assorted pork loin chops" that were really cheap on sale, but they weren't very cleanly cut and had fat in seemingly random places, making this hard to eat. A higher quality of meat would have made eating this dish more enjoyable. I cut the recipe down to four chops instead of six (although I kept the same amount of sauce). The chops were so big that only two would fit in the skillet at the same time, and I could barely squeeze the four chops in the 9x13. I followed the suggestion of another reviewer and sauted 8 oz of sliced fresh mushrooms in the pan I used to fry the chops in and put that into the sauce. I baked my chops for 35 minutes and then checked the temps, and they were about 190-200 degrees at the thickest parts, so definately done! I added the sauce and baked 20 minutes more. Next time I think I will just heat the sauce up on the stove, because it made the breading very mushy.

text:
This recipe was extremely flavorful, and fairly easy to make. It was enjoyed by my whole family, including my parents who were eating with us at the time. I used fairly thin pork chops and used 9 of them since they were so thin. I also used 1/2 cup of wine and 1/3 cup of milk, instead of the opposite. And I heated the sauce in a pan on the stove before pouring it over the pork chops and baking them a bit longer, just due to the fact that my pork chops didn't need to spend much time in the oven. I did discover that you don't really need as many breadcrumbs as it calls for, so you can probably cut back on that. Otherwise, the wine gives the sauce and pork chops an excellent flavor, and I will definitely be using this recipe again.

None
text:
This looked like a pretty quick and simple recipe.  I used golden mushroom soup instead of regular cream of 'shroom, tasted the sauce and thought it needed some punch.  So I added hot sauce, red pepper flakes, salt, onion powder, minced garlic and a little bit on onion soup mix (all to taste, of course).  Baked the chops in the oven for 30 min, poured the sauce over and baked for another 20.  When they came out, they were juicy, and tender, no knife needed.

text:
I have to disagree with all of the rave reviews.  Perhaps, people have just had some really BAD pork chops so this tastes so good in comparison???  I don't know.  In all fairness, however, I will say that I used Golden Mushroom soup instead of Cream of Mushroom, so perhaps that makes all the difference. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly.  They came out nice and tender and the presentation was nice, but the taste was not.  Tasted like canned soup poured on top.  Nothing special and definitely not worth the time, mess and calories!  Surprisingly, however, my very picky 6-year-old loved this recipe.  I would have bet a million bucks she wouldn't have even tried it.  But she did and she even asked for seconds!  Later that evening, instead of sneaking some sort of sweets for dessert, I caught her picking the leftover chops!  Since nobody else in the family (even hubby who usually eats anything!) liked them, there's plenty for her to eat tomorrow, and the next night, and the next night...

I made a couple of changes - I used one can of cream of chicken along with one can of the cream of mushroom. I omitted the wine (didn't have any!) but I bet that would be good.  I also added some dried minced onion, a can of mushrooms (fresh would be awesome), paprika, coarse black pepper, and some garlic powder into the "gravy" before pouring it over the pork chops.  I used boneless chops - which I would recommend if time is short.  These are a keeper!

I made these for my New Year's Day DInner and served with cabbage and black eyed peas. My dad said these were some of the best pork chops he had ever tasted! I highly suggest the wine, it adds great flavor. The only change I made was adding some onion I chopped and sauteed with garlic to the soup mixture-I poured over the chops before baking. I thought about not cooking the whole 11/2 hours, it seemed so long. However, I did cook the whole 11/2 hours and they were so tender and delicous. I would defintely make these again, and would be great for company.

text:
Easy recipe! Really doesn't take that long to prepare since the prep-work is so simple.  Realized at the last minute that I didn't have bread crumbs so I substituted with crushed up Italian croutons.  Mmm...still nice n' crispy even after baking in the sauce!  Served with squash and and tossed salad.  My residential food critics (aka...kids!) liked it even though they questioned what exactly I was serving!  I used a family size mushroom soup & 3/4 can of milk.  Plenty of "gravey" to cover the chops and still had lots leftover!  I will use this recipe over and over again.

text:
As if this one needed another review, but...it was really great!  Very, very rich though, not something to have very often.  I followed the recipe exactly, except I used four pork chops and kept the full sauce amount to serve over rice.  I definately thing that the wine shouldn't be left out, if possible, because it really gives it a kick.  Also, as other reviewers have stated, don't be afraid of the 90 min. cooking time--I was, but they turned out beautifully.  We didn't even need knives.  Just be sure to use foil, otherwise it just wouldn't work.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe, because it's pretty forgiving.  I made it as-is the first time, and we both loved it.  It was a tiny bit bland, but I like that in recipes - it gives me a chance to modify to my taste.  I always cut the recipe in half.  After a few recipes, this time around turned out the worst ever - and I think I'd still give it a 5-star rating.  I used Shake-n-Bake on the pork (hot & spicy) and baked it at 400 for 12 minutes instead of frying the pork.  I lowered the temp to 350 (and started cooking the rice) and dumped in my mushroom soup mixture.  It was not condensed soup, so I skipped the additional milk, but I did add in about 1/2 cup of diced onion.    I cooked the pork another 35 minutes (it should have been about 20-25 min more).  The pork was slightly overcooked, but it had excellent flavor.  There was plenty of the soup to use over white rice, which is probably my favorite part.  It is very tasty!

I used 4 large 3/4" thick Pork Loin Chops boneless and marinated them for 4 hours in Italian Dressing.  I then breaded and fried the chops as directed.  I doubled the gravy recipe and substituted the cream of mushroom soup with cream of chicken & mushroom soup.  Also used chicken broth instead of wine.  My hubby and 10 year old daughter LOVED it. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very tasty way to do pork chops.  I used cream of celery, and added some sliced potatoes, carrots and a little onion, since I only had two pork chops to cook and didn't want to waste the sauce.  This worked really well, and turned it into a one dish meal instead of just the meat.  I cooked it for about 20 minutes without the sauce, then for about an hour after adding the sauce.  I also sprinkled some onion soup mix over the whole thing.  I think it is possible that others who found the meat slightly tough cooked it too little, rather than too long - I checked mine after 30 minutes with the sauce and found that the chops were not yet fork tender - after another thirty minutes they were perfect.  If you cook pork chops with sauce in a covered dish, they are not going to toughen with longer cooking - if anything, they will get too mushy.  Although I did add some extra ingredients, I really did not change the basic recipe, and we enjoyed it very much - thanks!
Review:

text:
Very good.  Much better to do this way than just throw plain chops in and cover with soup.  I like the breading idea.  The cooking time is a little long, in my opinion.  I only cooked mine 30 minutes without the sauce, 30 minutes with...for a total of an hour, not an hour and a half.  My chops would have been extremely overcooked with an additional half hour of cooking.  Also, we don't drink, and I rarely buy wine just for cooking, so I used a little chicken broth to compensate.  Wonderful sauce, moist chops, great dinner.

favoritesCount:
32
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was such a winner! Even my husband liked it and he hates Pork Chops. A few changes I made: I skipped the bread crumbs and white wine. I left them out completely. I threw in some shitake mushrooms for texture and used Campbells Roasted Mushroom and Garlic soup (which made the gravy more brown than beige) and sprinkled with chopped parsely before serving for some much needed color. Otherwise, everyone loved it. Like another reviewer's recommendation, even though I used THICK chops, I baked for 30 minutes, poured in the soup, and then baked another 30 minutes for a total cook time of 1 hour. It think 1.5 hours would have been too much. These stayed very nice and moist.

text:
I was raised a vegetarian and I have never cooked or even eaten pork chops before.  My husband has been asking me to make some for quite some time so I finally decided to give it a try.  This recipe was so simple and tasty.  My husband gave it an A+ and said they were the best pork chops he has ever had!  I would recommend following the recipe precisely with the exception of cutting down on the cooking time in the oven.  Our "large" pork chops were done in just 45 minutes - if I had cooked them any longer they would have been dry.  A hour a half in the oven seems way too long.

text:
Everyone loved this!  I was cooking for a large group so I doubled the meat portion (12 chops) and quadrupled the gravy ingredients which ended up being 2 cans of cream of mushroom w/ garlic, 1 can regular cream of mushroom, and 1 can of cream of chicken & mushroom (that's what I had on hand).  I seasoned the 1/2" boneless chops with Natures Seasoning and garlic pepper and reduced the cook time to 45 minutes.  It was a huge hit!

text:
Excellent pork chop recipe!  I never make pork, but bought some chops earlier this week and figured it was time to try out some recipes.  My only criticism of this recipe was that my pork chops didn't come out as moist as described by all the other posts.  I also made a few changes; I omitted the seasoning salt (didn't have it, wasn't an issue), used cream of chicken (again, didn't have cream of mushroom) and added a can of green beans.  Even with the adjustments, it was still delicious!  My boyfriend was totally wowed and must have said "this is very good" about four times during dinner.  I will make this again!

text:
I have made this recipe so many times...but since it is summer I decided to try making it in the crock pot. It worked great! While preparing the pork chops I made a double recipe of the sauce and had it precooking in the crock pot. I then fried the pork chops and placed them in the crock pot for about 1.5 hours. Perfection! I am going to make them this way every time. Neither me or my husband noticed any difference in flavor.

text:
We had this for dinner last night and while it wasn't bad, it wasn't as wonderful as we hoped based on all the five-star ratings.  After reading the negative ratings, I think the problem might actually have been that folks used thick chops. Ours were bone-in center cut (not thick) and they were very tender and plenty moist.  My reason for the three-star rating is that I just didn't care for the flavor of the sauce.  Maybe too much wine, too much cream-of-mushroom -- the smell of the breaded chops frying was heavenly, but all you could taste was the cream stuff when it was all done.

text:
This is an excellent recipe! I did make a couple of changes! I used plain breadcrumbs and only needed 1 cup for 7 boneless chops.I also needed only 1 egg mixed with a little water to make an egg wash. I didn't have any wine so I just used 1 cup of 1% milk with the soup. I poured the soup mixture over the chops right after browning and covered with foil and baked 1 hr. They were fork tender and fabulous.My 14 yr old loved it and so did my husband...there was nothing left! I may add more soup and milk next time for even more sauce.We had it with buttered, boiled potatoes and green peas. It was great!

text:
The chops tasted pretty good, but the texture wasn't too pleasing. They turned out to be too dry, and the bread crumbs were kinda hard. I made some changes to the mushroom sauce, and it turned out well. I added more skimmed milk to water it down a bit and some sauteed, diced mushrooms and onions. I kept the extra sauce and put it on the side of the plate.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very easy to make, but a little bit bland for our taste. I reduced the fry time to about 3 minutes a side (just until golden brown), and the first hour of baking I reduced to 45 minutes, and still found them to be just a little bit dry (I was using boneless chops). I liked the flavor the wine lent to the sauce (to me the only real flavor in the dish), but my husband didn't like the wine gravy. I would make again, but would use lots more seasonings (mostly pepper, garlic, and something spicy), and maybe some mushrooms and onions.

text:
I made this and I thought it was pretty good.  I do think the baking time was WAY TOO LONG.  Pork can dry out fast.  I poked the chops several times with a fork and put some broth in the bottom of the pan just because every time I make pork it turns out dry.  But this worked good.  I think frying it in the oil helps with the moistness too as does the wine. I used white cooking wine.  Something about the wine that makes meat more moist.  The breading got a little soggy with all the stuff on top which was kinda gross but overall a good find. Thanks!

text:
These were the best pork chops I have ever made! I used boneless chops. I followed the recipe, except I didn't have but one can of cream of mushroom soup and I wanted to double the gravy like many cooks recommended. I did have a can of Golden Mushroom soup, so I used it and one can of cream of mushroom soup, 2/3 cup of wine and one cup of milk. I think the Golden Mushroom soup enhanced the gravy flavor. My hubby loved it . Usually, when we have baked pork chops, he turns up his nose--but not this time! You have got to try this recipe!!!

This was sensational!!! Although I was out of bread crumbs, I used crushed saltines instead and I had no seasoning salt so I used Monterey Style Roasted Garlic and Red Bell Pepper seasoning with Monreal chicken seasoning and rather than sprinkle over the chops, I blended it with the saltines. I didn't have any soup handy so I used what I had and that was roasted chicken gravy. With all the different spices and seasonings that I used, it really couldn't have gone wrong. It came out wonderful. Thank you for the great cooking idea. I will make this very often. Finger licken Good!

text:
I read many reviews and decided to try the recipe. I used 1 inch thick chops and browned them in a non stick pan.  They looked great.  They smelled even better when they were baking.  I baked them a little longer and at 325.  When I added the mushroom soup, I increased the milk to 1 cup.  The sauce when they are done doesn't taste or look like mushroom soup.  I added a little water and mixed in the browned bits to make a nice gravy after I removed the chops from the baking dish. It was delicious.

text:
Everyone but my 3 year-old loved this dish.  I only baked the chops for about 45 minutes as opposed to the whole hour, then added the sauce and continued.  I loved the way the pork chops were very tender, and stayed crispy even in the sauce (if browned long enough--not sure 5 min. per side is enough).  I served w/ rice and green beans, it was delicious.

text:
I had no milk or white wine when I decided to make this for dinner tonight, so I substituted a little over 1/2 cup of Bass Ale for the white wine.  As for the milk, I assumed the purpose was to dilute the condensed mushroom soup a bit, so I merely filled the soup can halfway with water & added it to the mixture.  For the baking time, I did 45/40 & the results were absolutely yummy.  My husband was impressed with the way the chops were fork-tender.  I will definitely be making this again.

minutes?  We really like the flavor, so I'll try this again without the coating.  Any
suggestions?
